Ğ° - Wiktionary

Russian

Etymology 1

See Translingual section.

Pronunciation

  • IPA(key): [a]
  • Audio
    		(file)

Letter

Ğ° â€¢ (a) (lower case, upper case Ğ)

  1. The first letter of the Russian Cyrillic alphabet. It is followed by the letter Ğ± (b).
  2. The name of the Roman letter A, a in Russian.
Usage notes

The Russian name for Ğ° (a) is Ğ° (Ä), and in stressed syllables it has the sound of the long a in father. In unstressed positions, it is pronounced as a schwa, like the o in mother. (Unstressed Russian Ğ° (a) is pronounced the same as unstressed Russian Ğ¾ (o).)

Etymology 2

From Proto-Slavic *a (â€œand, butâ€), from Proto-Balto-Slavic *Å, from Proto-Indo-European *hâ‚Åd (presumed to be the ablative of *Ã©y, hâ‚e). Cognate with Lithuanian Ãµ (â€œand, butâ€).

Possible link with Lithuanian arÌƒ (â€œquestion particleâ€). Compare Russian Ğ° (a, â€œand, butâ€), Ğ¸ (i, â€œandâ€) and Ğ´Ğ° (da, â€œand, butâ€) with Lithuanian arÌƒ (â€œif, whetherâ€), irÌƒ (â€œandâ€) and dÃ¡r (â€œstill, yetâ€).

Pronunciation

  • Audio (stressed)
    		(file)
  • (stressed) IPA(key): [a]
  • (unstressed) IPA(key): [É™]
  • (unstressed, pre-tonal) IPA(key): [É]

Conjunction

Ğ° â€¢ (a)

  1. but, and (introduces a new or different meaning).
    Ğ¡ĞµĞ³Ğ¾ÌĞ´Ğ½Ñ Ñ‚ĞµĞ¿Ğ»Ğ¾Ì, Ğ° Ğ²Ñ‡ĞµÑ€Ğ°Ì Ğ±Ñ‹ÌĞ»Ğ¾ Ñ…Ğ¾ÌĞ»Ğ¾Ğ´Ğ½Ğ¾ â€• SevÃ³dnja teplÃ³, a vÄerÃ¡ bÃ½lo xÃ³lodno â€• It is warm today, but yesterday it was cold.
    Ğ­ÌÑ‚Ğ¾ Ğ½Ğµ ÑÌĞ±Ğ»Ğ¾ĞºĞ¾, Ğ° Ğ³Ñ€ÑƒÌÑˆĞ° â€• Ã‰to ne jÃ¡bloko, a grÃºÅ¡a â€• This is not an apple, but a pear.
    Ğ Ñ‡Ñ‚Ğ¾? â€• A Å¡to? â€• Why so?
    Ğ° Ñ‚Ğ¾ â€• a to â€• or else

Etymology 3

Compare Lithuanian Ã , Ãµ, oÃ  (â€œexpression of pain, surpriseâ€), as well as Gothic ğ‰ (Å, â€œah!â€), Latin Ä, Äh (â€œexpression of pain, angerâ€), Ancient Greek á¼† (Ã¢, â€œah!â€)

Alternative forms

  • Ğ°Ğ° (aa), Ğ°-Ğ° (a-a)

Pronunciation

  • IPA(key): [a]
  • Audio

Interjection

Ğ° â€¢ (a)!

  1. well! (expressing surprise)

Particle

Ğ° â€¢ (a)

  1. (colloquial particle used to seek confirmation) eh
    Ğ¢Ñ‹ ÑĞ»Ñ‹ÌÑˆĞ¸ÑˆÑŒ Ğ¼ĞµĞ½ÑÌ, Ğ°? â€• Ty slÃ½Å¡iÅ¡Ê¹ menjÃ¡, a? â€• Do you hear me, eh?
    Ğ¢Ñ‹ Ğ¿Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ´Ñ‘ÑˆÑŒ ÑĞµĞ³Ğ¾ÌĞ´Ğ½Ñ, Ğ°? â€• Ty pridjÃ³Å¡Ê¹ sevÃ³dnja, a? â€• So are you coming today, then?

Etymology 4

Abbreviation of Ğ°Ğ¼Ğ¿ĞµÌÑ€ (ampÃ©r).

Pronunciation

Noun

Ğ° â€¢ (a)Â mÂ inan (indeclinable)

  1. A, amp, ampere

Pronunciation

Ğ±ĞµĞ· - Wiktionary

Russian

Etymology

From Proto-Slavic *bez (â€œwithoutâ€), from Proto-Indo-European *bÊ°eÇµÊ°-

Cognate with Lithuanian bÃ¨ (â€œwithout; besidesâ€), Latvian bez (â€œwithoutâ€), Old Prussian bhe (â€œwithoutâ€), Sanskrit à¤¬à¤¹à¤¿à¤¸à¥ (bahÃ­s, â€œoutsideâ€), Persian Ø¨ÛŒâ€ (bi, â€œwithoutâ€)

Pronunciation

  • IPA(key): [bÊ²Éªs]
  • audio
    		(file)
  • Homophone: Ğ±ĞµÑ (bes)

Preposition

Ğ±ĞµĞ· â€¢ (bez) (+ genitive case)

  1. without
    Ğ±ĞµĞ· Ğ²Ğ¾Ğ´Ñ‹Ì â€• bez vodÃ½ â€• without water
    Ğ±ĞµÌĞ·Ğ¾ Ğ²ÑĞµĞ³Ğ¾Ì â€• bÃ©zo vsevÃ³ â€• without anything
    Ğ½Ğµ Ğ±ĞµĞ· Ğ¸Ğ½Ñ‚ĞµÑ€ĞµÌÑĞ° â€• ne bez interÃ©sa â€• not without interest
    Ğ±ĞµĞ· ÑĞ¾Ğ¼Ğ½ĞµÌĞ½Ğ¸Ñ â€• bez somnÃ©nija â€• without doubt
    ĞĞµ Ğ¼Ğ¾Ğ³ÑƒÌ Ğ¶Ğ¸Ñ‚ÑŒ Ğ±ĞµĞ· Ñ‚ĞµĞ±ÑÌ
    Ne mogÃº Å¾itÊ¹ bez tebjÃ¡
    I can't live without you.
  2. minus
    Ğ±ĞµĞ· Ñ‡ĞµÌÑ‚Ğ²ĞµÑ€Ñ‚Ğ¸ Ñ‡Ğ°Ñ â€• bez ÄÃ©tverti Äas â€• a quarter to one (literally, â€œless a quarter one oâ€™clockâ€)

Usage notes

Ğ±ĞµÌĞ·Ğ¾ (bÃ©zo) is used before some awkward consonant clusters.

Related terms

  • Ğ±ĞµĞ·- (bez-)

Ğ±Ñ‹ - Wiktionary

Russian

Alternative forms

  • Ğ± (b) (abbreviation, especially after vowels)
  • ĞºĞ°Ğ±Ñ‹Ì (kabÃ½) (colloquial)

Etymology

The word was the third-person singular aorist of Ğ±Ñ‹Ñ‚ÑŒ (bytÊ¹, â€œto beâ€), an otherwise obsolete Russian tense (see Old Church Slavonic Ğ±ê™‘Ñ‚Ğ¸ (byti)).

Pronunciation

  • IPA(key): [bÉ¨]
  • Audio
    		(file)

Particle

Ğ±Ñ‹ â€¢ (by)

  1. A verbal particle used to render conditional and subjunctive patterns
    Ğ¯ Ğ³Ğ¾Ğ²Ğ¾Ñ€Ğ¸ÌĞ». â€• Ja govorÃ­l. â€• I spoke.
    Ğ¯ Ğ±Ñ‹ Ğ³Ğ¾Ğ²Ğ¾Ñ€Ğ¸ÌĞ». â€• Ja by govorÃ­l. â€• I would (should) have spoken.; I would speak.; I might speak.

Usage notes

  • The particle Ğ±Ñ‹ is often shortened to Ğ± (b).
  • The particle Ğ±Ñ‹ may come before or after the verb it is targeting.
  • The particle Ğ±Ñ‹ is often omitted in colloquial settings. For example:
  • ÑĞ»Ğ¾Ğ²Ğ½Ğ¾ Ğ±Ñ‹ â†’ ÑĞ»Ğ¾Ğ²Ğ½Ğ¾ (Ğ±Ñ‹)

Related terms

  • ĞµÌÑĞ»Ğ¸ Ğ±Ñ‹ Ñ‚Ğ¾ÌĞ»ÑŒĞºĞ¾ (jÃ©sli by tÃ³lÊ¹ko)
  • ĞºĞ°ÌĞº Ğ±Ñ‹ Ğ½Ğµ (kÃ¡k by ne)
  • ÑĞ»Ğ¾ÌĞ²Ğ½Ğ¾ Ğ±Ñ‹ (slÃ³vno by)
  • Ñ‡Ñ‚Ğ¾ÌĞ±Ñ‹ (Å¡tÃ³by)

Ğ² - Wiktionary

Russian

Etymology 1

This entry lacks etymological information. If you are familiar with the origin of this term, please add it to the page per etymology instructions. You can also discuss it at the Etymology scriptorium.

Pronunciation

  • IPA(key): [vÉ›]Â (phonetic respelling: Ğ²Ñ)

Letter

Wikipedia has an article on:
Ve (Cyrillic)
Wikipedia

Ğ² â€¢ (v) (lower case, upper case Ğ’) (italics: Ğ’, Ğ²)

  1. The third letter of the Russian Cyrillic alphabet. Its name is Ğ²Ñ (vÉ›) and it has the sound of English v. It is preceded by Ğ‘ and followed by Ğ“.
See also
  • Search en.wiktionary.org for articles beginning with: Ğ’, Ğ²

Etymology 2

From Old East Slavic Ğ²ÑŠ (vÅ­), from Proto-Slavic *vÑŠ(n), from Proto-Indo-European *hâ‚nÌ¥, zero-grade form of *hâ‚Ã©n.

Alternative forms

  • Ğ²Ğ¾ (vo) (before certain consonant clusters)

Pronunciation

  • IPA(key): [v] (before vowels and voiced consonants)
  • IPA(key): [f] (before voiceless consonants)
  • Audio
    		(file)

Preposition

Ğ² â€¢ (v)

  1. (location) in, at, on (+ prepositional)
    ĞĞ½ Ğ² Ñ‚ĞµĞ°ÌÑ‚Ñ€Ğµ â€• On v teÃ¡tre â€• Heâ€™s at (in) the theater.
  2. (direction) to, into (+ accusative)
    ĞĞ½ Ğ¸Ğ´Ñ‘Ñ‚ Ğ² Ñ‚ĞµĞ°ÌÑ‚Ñ€ â€• On idjÃ³t v teÃ¡tr â€• Heâ€™s going to (into) the theater.
  3. (time) at, in, on (+ accusative)
    Ğ² Ñ‚Ñ€Ğ¸ Ñ‡Ğ°ÑĞ°Ì â€• v tri ÄasÃ¡ â€• at three oâ€™clock
    Ğ² Ğ¿ÑÌÑ‚Ğ½Ğ¸Ñ†Ñƒ â€• v pjÃ¡tnicu â€• on Friday
  4. per
    Ñ‚Ñ€Ğ¸ Ñ€Ğ°ÌĞ·Ğ° Ğ² Ğ´ĞµĞ½ÑŒ â€• tri rÃ¡za v denÊ¹ â€• three times per day
Related terms
  • Ğ²- (v-), Ğ²Ğ¾- (vo-)

Etymology 3

Abbreviation of Ğ²Ğ¾Ğ»ÑŒÑ‚ (volÊ¹t).

Pronunciation

  • IPA(key): [volÊ²t]Â (phonetic respelling: Ğ²Ğ¾Ğ»ÑŒÑ‚)

Ğ² â€¢ (v)Â mÂ inan (indeclinable)

  1. V, volt

Russian

Ğ²Ğ´Ğ²Ğ¾Ñ‘Ğ¼ â€¢ (vdvojÃ³m)

  1. two (together), both (together)
    Ñ‡Ğ°Ğ¹ Ğ²Ğ´Ğ²Ğ¾Ñ‘Ğ¼ â€• Äaj vdvojÃ³m â€• tea for two

Ğ²ĞµÑÑŒ - Wiktionary

Russian

A user suggests that this Russian entry be cleaned up, giving the reason: "the pronoun and adjective senses are mixed together and need to be carefully picked apart".
Please see the discussion on Requests for cleanup(+) for more information and remove this template after the problem has been dealt with.

Pronunciation

  • IPA(key): [vÊ²esÊ²]
  • Audio
    		(file)

Etymology 1

From Proto-Slavic *vÑŒÅ›ÑŒ.

Determiner

Ğ²ĞµÑÑŒ â€¢ (vesÊ¹)

  1. all, the whole, the whole of
    Ğ²ĞµÑÑŒ Ğ´ĞµĞ½ÑŒ â€• vesÊ¹ denÊ¹ â€• all day; all day long
    Ğ²ĞµÑÑŒ Ğ³Ñ€ÑÌĞ·Ğ½Ñ‹Ğ¹ â€• vesÊ¹ grjÃ¡znyj â€• dirty all over, all dirty
    Ğ²ĞµÑÑŒ Ğ² ÑĞ½ĞµĞ³ÑƒÌ â€• vesÊ¹ v snegÃº â€• covered with snow
    Ğ²ÑĞµĞ³Ğ¾Ì â€• vsevÃ³ â€• in all; altogether; sum total
    Ğ²ÑĞµĞ³Ğ¾Ì Ñ…Ğ¾Ñ€Ğ¾ÌÑˆĞµĞ³Ğ¾ â€• vsevÃ³ xorÃ³Å¡evo â€• all the best; good luck
    Ğ»ÑƒÌÑ‡ÑˆĞµ Ğ²ÑĞµĞ³Ğ¾Ì â€• lÃºÄÅ¡e vsevÃ³ â€• best of all
    Ğ²Ğ¾ Ğ²ÑÑ‘Ğ¼ Ğ¼Ğ¸ÌÑ€Ğµ â€• vo vsjom mÃ­re â€• all over the world
    Ğ¸ÌĞ·Ğ¾ Ğ²ÑĞµÑ… ÑĞ¸Ğ» â€• Ã­zo vsex sil â€• with all oneâ€™s might
    Ğ¿Ğ¾ Ğ²ÑĞµĞ¹ ÑÑ‚Ñ€Ğ°Ğ½ĞµÌ â€• po vsej stranÃ© â€• throughout the country
    Ğ¿Ñ€Ğ¸ Ğ²ÑÑ‘Ğ¼ Ñ‚Ğ¾Ğ¼ â€• pri vsjÃ³m tom â€• for all that
  2. everything, all
  3. everybody, everyone
Usage notes

Ğ²ĞµÑÑŒ (vesÊ¹) and its various forms can be used both as adjectives and as pronouns. As adjectives, the forms of Ğ²ĞµÑÑŒ (vesÊ¹) correspond roughly to the English adjectives all and every. When used as pronouns, Ğ²ÑĞµ (vse) means everyone, and Ğ²ÑÑ‘ (vsjo) means everything or all. For example,

  • ĞĞ½ ÑĞ¸Ğ´Ğ¸ÌÑ‚ Ğ·Ğ° ĞºĞ¾Ğ¼Ğ¿ÑŒÑÌÑ‚ĞµÑ€Ğ¾Ğ¼ Ğ²ĞµÑÑŒ Ğ´ĞµĞ½ÑŒ. - He sits at the computer all day.
  • ĞĞ½Ğ¸Ì ÑÑŠĞµÌĞ»Ğ¸ Ğ²ÑÑ ĞµĞ´ÑƒÌ. â€” They ate all the food.
  • ĞœÑ‹ Ğ¾Ğ±Ğ¾ÑˆĞ»Ğ¸Ì Ğ²ÑĞµ Ğ¼Ğ°Ğ³Ğ°Ğ·Ğ¸ÌĞ½Ñ‹. â€” We went to all the stores.
  • ĞŸĞ¾Ñ‡Ñ‚Ğ¸Ì Ğ²ÑĞµ Ğ±Ñ‹ÌĞ»Ğ¸ Ğ½Ğ° ĞºĞ¾Ğ½Ñ†ĞµÌÑ€Ñ‚Ğµ. â€” Almost everyone was at the concert.
  • Ğ’ÑÑ‘ Ñ…Ğ¾Ñ€Ğ¾ÑˆĞ¾Ì, Ñ‡Ñ‚Ğ¾ Ñ…Ğ¾Ñ€Ğ¾ÑˆĞ¾Ì ĞºĞ¾Ğ½Ñ‡Ğ°ÌĞµÑ‚ÑÑ. â€” Allâ€™s well that ends well.

Ğ²ÑÑ‘ - Wiktionary

Russian

  • Audio
    		(file)

Ğ²ÑÑ‘ â€¢ (vsjo)

  1. always, all the time
  2. only, just
    Ğ²ÑÑ‘ Ğ±Ğ¾ÌĞ»ÑŒÑˆĞµ Ğ¸ Ğ±Ğ¾ÌĞ»ÑŒÑˆĞµ â€• vsjÃ³ bÃ³lÊ¹Å¡e i bÃ³lÊ¹Å¡e â€• more and more

Pronoun

  1. all, the whole, the whole of, everything

  • Ñ€Ğ°Ğ²Ğ½Ğ¾Ğ´ÑƒÌÑˆĞ¸Ğµ (ravnodÃºÅ¡ije)
  • Ñ€Ğ°Ğ²Ğ½Ğ¾Ğ´ÑƒÌÑˆĞ½Ñ‹Ğ¹ (ravnodÃºÅ¡nyj)

Etymology 2

Pronunciation

  • IPA(key): [ËˆduÊ‚É™]
  • Audio

Noun

Ğ´ÑƒÌÑˆĞ° â€¢ (dÃºÅ¡a)Â mÂ inan

Ğ¶Ğ°Ğ»ÑŒ - Wiktionary

Russian

Pronunciation

  • IPA(key): [ÊalÊ²]
  • Audio
    		(file)

Etymology 1

Adverbial form made from Ğ¶Ğ°ÌĞ»Ğ¾ÑÑ‚ÑŒ (Å¾Ã¡lostÊ¹).

Predicative

Ğ¶Ğ°Ğ»ÑŒ â€¢ (Å¾alÊ¹) (invariable, impersonal form)

  1. it's a pity
  2. (with the subject in the dative) pities, is sorry
    Ğ•Ğ¼ÑƒÌ Ğ¶Ğ°Ğ»ÑŒ ĞµÑ‘. â€• JemÃº Å¾alÊ¹ jejÃ³. â€• He pities her.
    ĞœĞ½Ğµ Ğ¶Ğ°Ğ»ÑŒ ÑĞ¼Ğ¾Ñ‚Ñ€ĞµÌÑ‚ÑŒ Ğ½Ğ° Ğ½ĞµÑ‘. â€• Mne Å¾alÊ¹ smotrÃ©tÊ¹ na nejÃ³. â€• It grieves me to look at her.
    Ğ•Ğ¼ÑƒÌ Ğ¶Ğ°Ğ»ÑŒ ĞºÑƒÑĞºĞ°Ì Ñ…Ğ»ĞµÌĞ±Ğ°. â€• JemÃº Å¾alÊ¹ kuskÃ¡ xlÃ©ba. â€• He begrudges a crust of bread.
    Ğ¾ÌÑ‡ĞµĞ½ÑŒ Ğ¶Ğ°Ğ»ÑŒ. â€• Ã³ÄenÊ¹ Å¾alÊ¹. â€• more's the pity.
    ĞºĞ°Ğº Ğ¶Ğ°Ğ»ÑŒ! â€• kak Å¾alÊ¹! â€• what a pity!

Ğ¸ - Wiktionary

Russian

Pronunciation

  • IPA(key): [i]
  • audio
    		(file)

Etymology 1

From Early Cyrillic letter iÅ¾e, from Greek Î— (â€œetaâ€).

Letter

Ğ¸ â€¢ (i) (lower case, upper case Ğ˜) (italics: Ğ˜, Ğ¸)

  1. The tenth letter of the Russian Cyrillic alphabet. Its name is Ğ¸ (i) and is usually pronounced /i/, but unstressed or after certain consonants it merges with Ñ‹ into /Éª/. It is preceded by Ğ— (Z) and followed by Ğ™ (J).
See also
  • Wikipedia article on the Cyrillic alphabet
  • Search en.wiktionary.org for articles beginning with: Ğ˜, Ğ¸

Noun

Ğ¸ â€¢ (i)Â nÂ inan (indeclinable)

  1. The Cyrillic letter Ğ˜ (I), Ğ¸ (i).
  2. (Roman letter) I, i
  3. (English letter) E, e

Etymology 2

From Proto-Slavic *i, from Proto-Indo-European *ei, an early locative singular determiner, formed from the root *hâ‚e-, *hâ‚o-. Compare Greek Îµá¼° (eá¼°, â€œifâ€), Gothic ğŒ´ğŒ¹ (ei, â€œand, so that, be itâ€). Follows from ablative Proto-Indo-European *ed.

Conjunction

Ğ¸ â€¢ (i)

  1. and
    Ğ’Ğ¾Ñ‚ ÑÌĞ±Ğ»Ğ¾ĞºĞ¾ Ğ¸ Ğ³Ñ€ÑƒÌÑˆĞ°.
    Vot jÃ¡bloko i grÃºÅ¡a.
    Hereâ€™s an apple and a pear.
  2. as well as, both ... and ...
    Ğ Ğ¾ÑÑĞ¸ÌĞ¸ Ğ½ÑƒĞ¶Ğ½Ñ‹Ì Ğ¸ Ğ°ÌÑ€Ğ¼Ğ¸Ñ, Ğ¸ Ñ„Ğ»Ğ¾ÌÑ‚.
    RossÃ­i nuÅ¾nÃ½ i Ã¡rmija, i flÃ³t.
    Russia needs an army as well as a navy.
  3. even
    Ğ‘Ğ¾ÑÌÑÑŒ Ğ´Ğ°Ğ½Ğ°ÌĞ¹Ñ†ĞµĞ² Ğ¸ Ğ´Ğ°Ñ€Ñ‹Ì Ğ¿Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ¾ÑÑÌÑ‰Ğ¸Ñ…
    BojÃºsÊ¹ danÃ¡jcev i darÃ½ prinosjÃ¡Å¡Äix
    I fear the Danaans [Greeks], even those bearing gifts.
Synonyms
  • (and): Ğ° (a)

Etymology 3

This entry lacks etymological information. If you are familiar with the origin of this term, please add it to the page per etymology instructions. You can also discuss it at the Etymology scriptorium.

Particle

Ğ¸ â€¢ (i)

  1. (preceding a verb) Emphasizes the truth of the following verb. Note that "ĞµÑÑ‚ÑŒ (jestÊ¹)" is also used, which is usually omitted.
    ĞĞ½ Ñ‚Ğ°Ğº Ğ¸ Ğ´ĞµÌĞ»Ğ°ĞµÑ‚.
    On tak i dÃ©lajet.
    He does do it that way.
    ĞĞ½Ğ°Ì Ğ¸ Ğ¿Ğ¾ÑˆĞ»Ğ°Ì Ñ‚ÑƒĞ´Ğ°Ì.
    OnÃ¡ i poÅ¡lÃ¡ tudÃ¡.
    She did go there.
    ĞĞ½Ğ¾Ì Ğ¸ ĞµÑÑ‚ÑŒ Ñ‚Ğ°ĞºĞ¾ÌĞµ.
    OnÃ³ i jestÊ¹ takÃ³je.
    It is like that.
    Ğ¯ Ğ¸ ĞµÑÑ‚ÑŒ Ñ‚Ğ¾Ñ‚ Ñ‡ĞµĞ»Ğ¾Ğ²ĞµÌĞº.
    Ja i jestÊ¹ tot ÄelovÃ©k.
    I am that person.

Ğ¸Ğ´Ñ‚Ğ¸ - Wiktionary

Russian

Alternative forms

  • Ğ¸Ñ‚Ñ‚Ğ¸Ì (ittÃ­) (obsolete)
  • Ğ¸Ñ‚Ğ¸Ì (itÃ­) (obsolete)

Etymology

From Old East Slavic Ğ¸Ñ‚Ğ¸ (iti), from Proto-Slavic *jÑŒti (â€œto goâ€). The infinitive spelled with Ğ´ (d) is attested since the 14th century, under influence of Ğ¸Ğ´ÑƒÌ (idÃº), Ğ¸Ğ´Ñ‘ÑˆÑŒ (idjÃ³Å¡Ê¹), etc.

Pronunciation

  • IPA(key): [ÉªËˆtÊ²Ëi]
  • Audio
    		(file)
Ğ˜Ğ´Ñ‚Ğ¸.

Verb

Ğ¸Ğ´Ñ‚Ğ¸Ì â€¢ (idtÃ­)Â impf (perfective Ğ¿Ğ¾Ğ¹Ñ‚Ğ¸Ì) (concrete verbs)

  1. to go
    Ğ˜Ğ´Ñ‘Ğ¼ Ğ² ĞºĞ¸Ğ½Ğ¾Ñ‚ĞµĞ°ÌÑ‚Ñ€! â€• IdjÃ³m v kinoteÃ¡tr! â€• Let's go to the movie theater!
  2. to walk
  3. (of precipitation) to fall
    Ğ˜Ğ´Ñ‘Ñ‚ Ğ´Ğ¾Ğ¶Ğ´ÑŒ. â€• IdjÃ³t doÅ¾dÊ¹. â€• Itâ€™s raining.
    Ğ˜Ğ´Ñ‘Ñ‚ ÑĞ½ĞµĞ³. â€• IdjÃ³t sneg. â€• Itâ€™s snowing.
    Ğ˜Ğ´Ñ‘Ñ‚ Ğ³Ñ€Ğ°Ğ´. â€• IdjÃ³t grad. â€• Itâ€™s hailing.
  4. to function, work
    Ğ­ÌÑ‚Ğ¸ Ñ‡Ğ°ÑÑ‹Ì Ğ½Ğµ Ğ¸Ğ´ÑƒÌÑ‚. â€• Ã‰ti ÄasÃ½ ne idÃºt. â€• This clock/watch doesn't work.
  5. to suit, become (of wearing clothes)
    Ğ­ÌÑ‚Ğ¾Ñ‚ ĞºĞ¾ÑÑ‚ÑÌĞ¼ ĞµĞ¼ÑƒÌ Ğ¸Ğ´Ñ‘Ñ‚. â€• Ã‰tot kostjÃºm jemÃº idjÃ³t. â€• This suit suits him.
  6. (used in expressions)
    Ğ’Ñ€ĞµÌĞ¼Ñ Ğ¸Ğ´Ñ‘Ñ‚ Ğ±Ñ‹ÌÑÑ‚Ñ€Ğ¾. â€• VrÃ©mja idjÃ³t bÃ½stro. â€• Time flies.
    Ğ­ÌÑ‚Ğ¾ ĞµÑ‰Ñ‘ ĞºÑƒĞ´Ğ°Ì Ğ½Ğ¸ ÑˆĞ»Ğ¾. â€• Ã‰to jeÅ¡ÄÃ³ kudÃ¡ ni Å¡lo. â€• That's still all right. (colloquial)

Usage notes

  • Ğ˜Ğ´Ñ‚Ğ¸ and Ğ¿Ğ¾Ğ¹Ñ‚Ğ¸Ì (pojtÃ­) are Russian concrete verbs. Their counterpart, Ñ…Ğ¾Ğ´Ğ¸ÌÑ‚ÑŒ (xodÃ­tÊ¹), is an abstract verb.
  • Prefixed derivatives of this verb are formed using the combining form -Ğ¹Ñ‚Ğ¸Ì (-jtÃ­).

  • ÑĞ½Ğ¸ÑÑ…Ğ¾Ğ´Ğ¸ÌÑ‚ÑŒ (snisxodÃ­tÊ¹)
  • ÑÑ…Ğ¾Ğ´Ğ¸ÌÑ‚ÑŒ (sxodÃ­tÊ¹)

Ğº - Wiktionary

Russian

Etymology 1

Pronunciation

  • IPA(key): [k]
  • Audio
    		(file)

Letter

Ğº â€¢ (k) (lower case, upper case Ğš)

  1. The twelfth letter of the Russian Cyrillic alphabet. Its name is ĞºĞ° (ka) and it has the sound of English k. It is preceded by Ğ™ (J) and followed by Ğ› (L).

Etymology 2

From Proto-Slavic *kÑŠ(n).

Preposition

Ğº â€¢ (k) (+ dative case)

  1. to, toward
    Ğº Ğ´Ğ¾Ğ¼Ñƒ (domu) â€” to the house
    Ğº Ğ±Ñ€Ğ°ÌÑ‚Ñƒ â€• k brÃ¡tu â€• to (my) brother
    ĞºĞ¾ Ğ¼Ğ½Ğµ (mne) â€” to me
  2. (time): by, for
    ĞºĞ¾ Ğ²Ñ‚Ğ¾Ñ€Ğ½Ğ¸ĞºÑƒ (vtorniku) â€” by Tuesday, for Tuesday
Usage notes

ĞºĞ¾ (ko) is used before words beginning with certain awkward consonant clusters such as Ğ¼Ğ½- (mn-), Ğ²Ñ- (vs-), Ğ²Ñ‚- (vt-), and ÑĞ½- (sn-).

Etymology 3

Abbreviation of ĞºĞ¸Ğ»Ğ¾- (kilo-).

Pronunciation

  • IPA(key): [kÊ²ÉªlÉ™]

Prefix

Ğº â€¢ (k)

  1. k, kilo- (x 1000)

ĞºĞ°Ğº - Wiktionary

Russian

Pronunciation

  • IPA(key): [kak]
  • Audio
    		(file)

Etymology 1

From Proto-Slavic *kako.

Adverb

ĞºĞ°Ğº â€¢ (kak)

  1. how
    ĞšĞ°Ğº Ğ¾Ğ½ ÑÌÑ‚Ğ¾ ÑĞ´ĞµÌĞ»Ğ°Ğ»? â€• Kak on Ã©to sdÃ©lal? â€• How did he do it?
    ĞšĞ°Ğº Ğ´ĞµĞ»Ğ°Ì? â€• Kak delÃ¡? â€• How are things?
    ĞšĞ°Ğº Ğ¿Ñ€Ğ¾Ğ¹Ñ‚Ğ¸Ì Ğ½Ğ° Ğ¿Ğ¾ÌÑ‡Ñ‚Ñƒ? â€• Kak projtÃ­ na pÃ³Ätu? â€• Can you tell me the way to the post office?
  2. what
    ĞšĞ°Ğº Ğ²Ğ°ÌÑˆĞ° Ñ„Ğ°Ğ¼Ğ¸ÌĞ»Ğ¸Ñ? â€• Kak vÃ¡Å¡a famÃ­lija? â€• What is your surname?
    ĞšĞ°Ğº Ğ²Ğ°Ñ Ğ·Ğ¾Ğ²ÑƒÌÑ‚? â€• Kak vas zovÃºt? â€• What is your name?
    ĞšĞ°Ğº Ğ¾Ğ½ ÑĞºĞ°Ğ·Ğ°ÌĞ»? â€• Kak on skazÃ¡l? â€• What did he say?
  3. as

  4. suddenly, all of a sudden
    ĞšĞ°Ğº Ğ¾Ğ½ Ğ²ÑĞºĞ¾ÌÑ‡Ğ¸Ñ‚! â€• Kak on vskÃ³Äit! â€• All of a sudden he jumped up!
    ĞºĞ°Ğº Ñ€Ğ°Ğ· â€• kak raz â€• just; just in time

    ĞšĞ°Ğº Ğ±Ñ‹ Ğ½Ğµ Ñ‚Ğ°ÌĞº! â€• Kak by ne tÃ¡k! â€• Not likely! Nothing of the sort!

ĞºĞ°Ğº â€¢ (kak)

  1. how
    Ğ¯ Ğ½Ğµ Ğ·Ğ½Ğ°ÌÑ, ĞºĞ°Ğº Ğ¾Ğ½ ÑÌÑ‚Ğ¾ ÑĞ´ĞµÌĞ»Ğ°Ğ» â€• Ja ne znÃ¡ju, kak on Ã©to sdÃ©lal â€• I donâ€™t know how he did it.

    Ğ‘ÑƒĞ´ÑŒÑ‚Ğµ ĞºĞ°Ğº Ğ´Ğ¾Ğ¼Ğ° â€• BudÊ¹te kak doma â€• Make yourself at home.

Ğ½Ğ° - Wiktionary

Russian

Etymology 1

From Proto-Slavic *na, from Proto-Indo-European *hâ‚‚nehâ‚ƒ.

Pronunciation

  • IPA(key): [nÉ™]
  • IPA(key): [Ëˆna] (when stressed)
  • Audio
    		(file)

Preposition

Ğ½Ğ° â€¢ (na) accusative case (movement towards):

  1. onto, on
    Ğ½Ğ° ÑÑ‚Ğ¾Ğ» â€• na stol â€• onto the table
  2. to, toward
    Ğ½Ğ° Ğ¿Ğ¾ÌÑ‡Ñ‚Ñƒ â€• na pÃ³Ätu â€• to the post office
  3. into, in
  4. (duration, value, purpose) for
    Ğ½Ğ° Ñ‡Ñ‚Ğ¾? â€• na Å¡to? â€• what for?
  5. about, for
    Ğ¾Ğ½ Ğ¾Ğ±ÑŠÑĞ²Ğ¸ÌĞ» Ğ¿Ñ€Ğ¾Ğ³Ñ€Ğ°Ğ¼Ğ¼Ñƒ Ğ½Ğ° ÑĞ»ĞµÌĞ´ÑƒÑÑ‰Ğ¸Ğ¹ Ğ´ĞµĞ½ÑŒ â€• on obÊºjavÃ­l programmu na slÃ©dujuÅ¡Äij denÊ¹ â€• He announced a program for the next day

prepositional case (position on):

ÑĞ¾Ğ±Ğ°ĞºĞ° Ğ½Ğ° [1] Ğ¿Ğ½Ğµ
  1. on, upon
    Ğ½Ğ° ÑÑ‚Ğ¾Ğ»ĞµÌ â€• na stolÃ© â€• on the table
  2. in, at
    Ğ½Ğ° Ğ¿Ğ¾ÌÑ‡Ñ‚Ğµ â€• na pÃ³Äte â€• at the post office
  3. with, for
Related terms
  • Ğ½Ğ°- (na-)

Etymology 2

This entry lacks etymological information. If you are familiar with the origin of this term, please add it to the page per etymology instructions. You can also discuss it at the Etymology scriptorium.

Pronunciation

  • IPA(key): [Ëˆna]

Particle

Ğ½Ğ° â€¢ (na)

  1. here! (said when giving someone something, i.e., "take it!")

Ğ¾ - Wiktionary

Russian

Etymology 1

Pronunciation

  • IPA(key): [o]
  • Audio
    		(file)

Letter

Ğ¾ â€¢ (o) (lower case, upper case Ğ)

  1. The sixteenth letter of the Russian Cyrillic alphabet.
See also
  • Previous letter: Ğ½ (n)
  • Next letter: Ğ¿ (p)

Noun

Ğ¾ â€¢ (o)Â nÂ inan (indeclinable)

  1. The Cyrillic letter Ğ (O), Ğ¾ (o).
  2. The Roman letter O, o.

Etymology 2

Pronunciation

  • IPA(key): [o]

Interjection

Ğ¾ â€¢ (o)

  1. oh
    Ğ Ğ±Ğ¾ÌĞ¶Ğµ! â€• O bÃ³Å¾e! â€• Oh God!

Etymology 3

From Proto-Slavic *o(b), from Proto-Indo-European *hâ‚ƒebÊ°i.

Pronunciation

  • Audio (stressed)
    		(file)
  • (stressed) IPA(key): [o]
  • (unstressed) IPA(key): [É™]
  • (unstressed, pre-tonal) IPA(key): [É]

Preposition

Ğ¾ â€¢ (o)

  1. (+ prepositional case) about, of, on
    Ğ¯ Ñ‡Ğ¸Ñ‚Ğ°ÌĞ» Ğ¾ Ğ½Ñ‘Ğ¼ â€• Ja ÄitÃ¡l o njÃ³m â€• Iâ€™ve read about him.
  2. (+ accusative case) against, upon
    Ğ¾Ğ¿Ğ¸Ñ€Ğ°ÌÑ‚ÑŒÑÑ Ğ¾ ÑÑ‚ĞµÌĞ½Ñƒ â€• opirÃ¡tÊ¹sja o stÃ©nu â€• to lean against the wall

Pronunciation and usage notes

The Ğ¾ form is unstressed except in the idiom Ğ±Ğ¾Ğº Ğ¾Ìâ€ Ğ±Ğ¾Ğº.

The form Ğ¾ is usually used before consonants. In some cases before consonants the form Ğ¾Ğ±Ğ¾ is used. Before an iotated vowel and before the pronoun Ğ¸Ñ… the forms Ğ¾Ğ± and o are used interchangeably.

Instead of ĞµĞ³Ğ¾, ĞµÑ‘, the forms beginning with Ğ½- are used: Ğ¾ Ğ½ĞµĞ³Ğ¾, Ğ¾ Ğ½ĞµÑ‘.

Alternative forms

  • Ğ¾Ğ± (ob) (before vowels and in some other cases)
  • Ğ¾Ğ±Ğ¾ (obo) (before some words such as Ğ¼Ğ½Ğµ or Ğ²ÑĞµ)

Ğ¾Ğ´Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ¾ĞºĞ¾ - Wiktionary

Russian

Etymology

Ğ¾Ğ´Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ¾ÌĞºĞ¸Ğ¹ (odinÃ³kij) +â€ -Ğ¾ (-o)

Pronunciation

  • IPA(key): [ÉdÊ²ÉªËˆnokÉ™]
  • Audio
    		(file)

Adverb

Ğ¾Ğ´Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ¾ÌĞºĞ¾ â€¢ (odinÃ³ko)

  1. alone
  2. in a lonely manner
    Ñ‡ÑƒÌĞ²ÑÑ‚Ğ²Ğ¾Ğ²Ğ°Ñ‚ÑŒ ÑĞµĞ±ÑÌ Ğ¾Ğ´Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ¾ÌĞºĞ¾ â€• ÄÃºvstvovatÊ¹ sebjÃ¡ odinÃ³ko â€• to feel lonely

Adjective

Ğ¾Ğ´Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ¾ÌĞºĞ¾ â€¢ (odinÃ³ko)

  1. short neuter singular of Ğ¾Ğ´Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ¾ÌĞºĞ¸Ğ¹ (odinÃ³kij)

Related terms

Ğ¾Ğ½Ğ° - Wiktionary

Russian

Etymology

From Proto-Slavic *ona.

Pronunciation

  • IPA(key): [ÉËˆna]
  • Audio
    		(file)

Pronoun

Ğ¾Ğ½Ğ°Ì â€¢ (onÃ¡) (masculine counterpart Ğ¾Ğ½, neuter counterpart Ğ¾Ğ½Ğ¾Ì)

  1. third-person feminine singular pronoun: she, it.
    Ğ”Ğ° ĞºĞ°Ğº Ğ¶Ğµ Ğ¾Ğ½Ğ°Ì, Ñ‚Ğ°Ğº Ğ¸ Ğ³Ğ¾Ğ²Ğ¾Ñ€Ğ¸ÌÑ‚? â€• Da kak Å¾e onÃ¡, tak i govorÃ­t? â€• What is she like? Does she talk?
    Ğ•Ñ‘ Ğ½ĞµÑ‚ Ğ´Ğ¾ÌĞ¼Ğ° (genitive) â€• JejÃ³ net dÃ³ma â€• Sheâ€™s not home.
    Ğ•Ğ¹ Ğ½Ğµ ÑĞ¿Ğ¸ÌÑ‚ÑÑ. (dative) â€• Jej ne spÃ­tsja. â€• She is unable to sleep.
    Ğ¯ Ğ²Ğ¸ÌĞ¶Ñƒ ĞµÑ‘. (accusative) â€• Ja vÃ­Å¾u jejÃ³. â€• I see her.
    Ğ—Ğ° Ğ½ĞµÌÑ Ğ¿ÑÑ‚ÑŒ Ñ€ÑƒĞ±Ğ»ĞµÌĞ¹. (instrumental) â€• Za nÃ©ju pjatÊ¹ rublÃ©j. â€• She owes five rubles.
    ĞĞ½ ÑÌÑ‚Ğ¾ Ğ¿Ñ€Ğ¸ Ğ½ĞµĞ¹ ÑĞºĞ°Ğ·Ğ°ÌĞ». (prepositional) â€• On Ã©to pri nej skazÃ¡l. â€• He said it in her presence.

Usage notes

  • Whenever a preposition stands immediately before any of the oblique cases of the third-person pronoun (singular or plural) and directly governs it, then an Ğ½- is prefixed to the pronoun: Ğ¾Ñ‚ Ğ½ĞµÑ‘ (ot nejÃ³, â€œfrom herâ€), Ğ½Ğ° Ğ½ĞµĞ¹ (na nej, â€œon herâ€), Ñƒ Ğ½ĞµÑ‘ (u nejÃ³, â€œshe hasâ€), Ğº Ğ½ĞµĞ¹ (k nej, â€œto herâ€), Ñ Ğ½ĞµÌÑ (s nÃ©ju, â€œwith herâ€).
  • The explanation for the Ğ½-prothesis is that, originally, some Russian prepositions ended in the letter -Ğ½: ÑÑŠĞ½ (sÅ­n, â€œwithâ€...cf. Greek ÏƒÏÎ½ (ÏƒÏÎ½), Latin cum). Eventually, the final Ğ½ of these prepositions migrated across to the pronoun, so that Ğ²ÑŠĞ½ ĞµÑ‘ became modern Ğ² Ğ½ĞµÑ‘ (v nejÃ³), and then this was extended to include all prepositions when governing any third-person pronoun.
  • Note that if the preposition does not directly govern ĞµÑ‘ (jejÃ³) (i.e., when ĞµÑ‘ is a possessive pronoun), then the Ğ½- is not inserted: Ñƒ ĞµÑ‘ Ğ±Ñ€Ğ°ÌÑ‚Ğ° (u jejÃ³ brÃ¡ta, â€œat her brotherâ€™sâ€), Ğ¾ ĞµÑ‘ Ğ¼Ğ°ÌÑ‚ĞµÑ€Ğ¸ (o jejÃ³ mÃ¡teri, â€œabout her motherâ€), Ğ² ĞµÑ‘ ĞºĞ¾ÌĞ¼Ğ½Ğ°Ñ‚Ğµ (v jejÃ³ kÃ³mnate, â€œin her roomâ€).
  • When there is another word separating a preposition and any oblique case of Ğ¾Ğ½Ğ°, the Ğ½- is not added: Ñƒ ÑĞ°Ğ¼Ğ¾ÌĞ¹ ĞµÑ‘ (u samÃ³j jejÃ³, â€œwith her herselfâ€).

(sebÃ©)
  1. The alternative forms starting with "Ğ½-" (n-) are used after a preposition.
  2. Letter "Ğ³" (g) in the genitive/accusative case ending is pronounced as /v/
  3. The prepositional case is never used without a preposition
  4. Instrumental forms ending in "-Ñ" (ju) are either dated, poetic, or dialectal.

(im, nim1) 		ĞµĞ¹, ĞµÌÑ4, Ğ½ĞµĞ¹1, Ğ½ĞµÌÑ1 4
(jej, jÃ©ju4, nej1, nÃ©ju1 4) 		Ğ½Ğ°ÌĞ¼Ğ¸
(nÃ¡mi) 		Ğ²Ğ°ÌĞ¼Ğ¸
(vÃ¡mi) 		Ğ¸ÌĞ¼Ğ¸, Ğ½Ğ¸ÌĞ¼Ğ¸1
(Ã­mi, nÃ­mi1) 		ÑĞ¾Ğ±Ğ¾ÌĞ¹, ÑĞ¾Ğ±Ğ¾ÌÑ4
(sobÃ³j, sobÃ³ju4)
prepositional3 Ğ¼Ğ½Ñ£
(mnÄ›) 		Ñ‚ĞµĞ±Ñ£Ì
(tebÄ›Ì) 		Ğ½Ñ‘Ğ¼ÑŠ1
(njom1) 		Ğ½ĞµĞ¹1
(nej1) 		Ğ½Ğ°ÑÑŠ
(nas) 		Ğ²Ğ°ÑÑŠ
(vas) 		Ğ½Ğ¸Ñ…ÑŠ1
(nix1) 		ÑĞµĞ±Ñ£Ì
(sebÄ›Ì)
  1. The alternative forms starting with "Ğ½-" (n-) are used after a preposition.
  2. Letter "Ğ³" (g) in the genitive/accusative case ending is pronounced as /v/
  3. The prepositional case is never used without a preposition
  4. Instrumental forms ending in "-Ñ" (ju) are either dated, poetic, or dialectal.

Related terms

  • ĞµÑ‘ (jejÃ³)
  • ÑĞ²Ğ¾Ğ¹ (svoj)

Ğ¾Ğ½Ğ¸ - Wiktionary

Russian

Etymology

Borrowed from Old Church Slavonic Ğ¾Ğ½Ğ¸ (oni), from Proto-Slavic *onÑŠ.

Pronunciation

  • IPA(key): [ÉËˆnÊ²i]
  • Audio
    		(file)

Pronoun

Ğ¾Ğ½Ğ¸Ì â€¢ (onÃ­)

  1. third-person plural pronoun: they.

Usage notes

  • An Ğ½ is prefixed to any third-person pronoun in an oblique case whenever a preposition that directly governs it is immediately in front of it: Ğ¾Ñ‚ Ğ½ĞµÑ‘ (ot nejÃ³) (from her), Ğ½Ğ° Ğ½Ñ‘Ğ¼ (na njom) (on him), Ñƒ Ğ½Ğ¸Ñ… (u nix) (they have), Ğº Ğ½ĞµĞ¼ÑƒÌ (k nemÃº) (to him), Ñ Ğ½ĞµÌÑ (s nÃ©ju) (with her).
  • This comes from Russian prepositions such as ÑÑŠĞ½ (sÅ­n, "with", cf. Greek ÏƒÏÎ½ (ÏƒÏÎ½), Latin cum), that originally ended in -Ğ½ and governed oblique cases. Since the prepositions and the pronouns occurred together so often, it was easy to lose track of which word the final -Ğ½ belonged to, and the Ğ½ was reinterpreted as part of the pronouns (Old English an, in the same way, lost its -n except before vowels, and sometimes gave it to the following word, as in English adder from Old English nÃ¦dre), so that ÑÑŠĞ½ Ğ¸ÌĞ¼Ğ¸ became modern Ñ Ğ½Ğ¸ÌĞ¼Ğ¸ (s nÃ­mi), and this new rule was extended to all prepositions governing any third-person pronoun.
  • That if the preposition does not directly govern ĞµĞ³Ğ¾Ì, ĞµÑ‘, Ğ¸Ñ… (jevÃ³, jejÃ³, ix) (i.e., when they are possessive pronouns), then no Ğ½- is inserted: Ñƒ ĞµĞ³Ğ¾Ì Ğ±Ñ€Ğ°ÌÑ‚Ğ° (u jevÃ³ brÃ¡ta) (at his brotherâ€™s), Ğ¾ ĞµÑ‘ Ğ¼Ğ°ÌÑ‚ĞµÑ€Ğ¸ (o jejÃ³ mÃ¡teri) (about her mother), Ğ² Ğ¸Ñ… ĞºĞ¾ÌĞ¼Ğ½Ğ°Ñ‚Ğµ (v ix kÃ³mnate) (in their room).

Ğ¾Ñ‚ - Wiktionary

Russian

Etymology

From Proto-Slavic *otÑŠ.

Pronunciation

  • IPA(key): [Ëˆot]
  • Audio
    		(file)

Preposition

Ğ¾Ñ‚ â€¢ (ot) (+ genitive case)

  1. from
    Ğ¾Ñ‚ Ğ´ÑƒÑˆĞ¸Ìâ€ â€• ot duÅ¡Ã­â€ â€• from the heart
  2. since

Usage notes

Before words beginning with certain awkward consonant clusters such as Ğ¼Ğ½- (mn-), Ğ²Ñ- (vs-), and ÑĞ½- (sn-), the variant form Ğ¾Ñ‚Ğ¾ (oto) is used.

Ğ¿ĞµÑ‡Ğ°Ğ»ÑŒ - Wiktionary

Russian

Pronunciation

  • IPA(key): [pÊ²ÉªËˆtÍ¡É•Ã¦lÊ²]

Etymology 1

From Old East Slavic Ğ¿ĞµÑ‡Ğ°Ğ»ÑŒ (peÄalÄ­, â€œgrief, censern, loathingâ€), from Proto-Slavic *peÄalÑŒ, from to bake

Noun

Ğ¿ĞµÑ‡Ğ°ÌĞ»ÑŒ â€¢ (peÄÃ¡lÊ¹)Â fÂ inan (genitive Ğ¿ĞµÑ‡Ğ°ÌĞ»Ğ¸, nominative plural Ğ¿ĞµÑ‡Ğ°ÌĞ»Ğ¸, genitive plural Ğ¿ĞµÑ‡Ğ°ÌĞ»ĞµĞ¹)

  1. sadness, grief, sorrow

      ĞŸĞµÑ‡Ğ°ÌĞ»ÑŒ Ğ¼Ğ¾ÑÌ Ğ¿Ğ¾Ğ»Ğ½Ğ°Ì Ñ‚Ğ¾Ğ±Ğ¾ÌÑ,
      Ğ¢Ğ¾Ğ±Ğ¾ÌĞ¹, Ğ¾Ğ´Ğ½Ğ¾ÌĞ¹ Ñ‚Ğ¾Ğ±Ğ¾ÌĞ¹... Ğ£Ğ½Ñ‹ÌĞ½ÑŒÑ Ğ¼Ğ¾ĞµĞ³Ğ¾Ì
      ĞĞ¸Ñ‡Ñ‚Ğ¾Ì Ğ½Ğµ Ğ¼ÑƒÌÑ‡Ğ¸Ñ‚, Ğ½Ğµ Ñ‚Ñ€ĞµĞ²Ğ¾ÌĞ¶Ğ¸Ñ‚,
      Ğ˜ ÑĞµÌÑ€Ğ´Ñ†Ğµ Ğ²Ğ½Ğ¾ÌĞ²ÑŒ Ğ³Ğ¾Ñ€Ğ¸ÌÑ‚ Ğ¸ Ğ»ÑÌĞ±Ğ¸Ñ‚ â€” Ğ¾Ñ‚Ñ‚Ğ¾Ğ³Ğ¾Ì,
      Ğ§Ñ‚Ğ¾ Ğ½Ğµ Ğ»ÑĞ±Ğ¸ÌÑ‚ÑŒ Ğ¾Ğ½Ğ¾Ì Ğ½Ğµ Ğ¼Ğ¾ÌĞ¶ĞµÑ‚.
      Na xÃ³lmax GrÃºzii leÅ¾Ã­t noÄnÃ¡ja mglÃ¡;
      Å umÃ­t ArÃ¡gva prÃ©do mnÃ³ju.
      Mne grÃºstno i lexkÃ³; peÄÃ¡lÊ¹ mojÃ¡ svetlÃ¡;

      TobÃ³j, odnÃ³j tobÃ³j... UnÃ½nÊ¹ja mojevÃ³

      I sÃ©rdce vnÃ³vÊ¹ gorÃ­t i ljÃºbit â€” ottovÃ³,
      Å to ne ljubÃ­tÊ¹ onÃ³ ne mÃ³Å¾et.

      Dark falls upon the hills of Georgia,
      I hear Aragva's roar.
      I'm sad and light, my griefâ€”transparent,
      My sorrow is suffused with you,
      With you, with you alone...My melancholy
      Remains untouched and undisturbed,
      And once again my heart ignites and loves
      Because it can't do otherwise.

Ğ¿Ğ¾Ğ´ - Wiktionary

Russian

Etymology

From Proto-Slavic *podÑŠ.

Pronunciation

  • IPA(key): [pÉ™t]
  • audio
    		(file)
  • Homophones: Ğ¿Ğ¾Ñ‚

Preposition

Ğ¿Ğ¾Ğ´ â€¢ (pod)

  1. (with accusative case)
    under (movement to beneath)
    towards, to
    about, on the eve of (time)
    in imitation of, Ã  la
    for, suitable as
  2. (with instrumental case)
    under, below, beneath (location)
    near, by
    used for

Usage notes

  • Ğ¿Ğ¾Ğ´Ğ¾ (podo) is used before words with certain awkward consonant clusters such as Ğ¼Ğ½- (mn-), Ğ²Ñ- (vs-), and ÑĞ½- (sn-).

Noun

Ğ¿Ğ¾Ğ´ â€¢ (pod)Â mÂ inan (genitive Ğ¿Ğ¾ÌĞ´Ğ°, nominative plural Ğ¿Ğ¾Ğ´Ñ‹Ì, genitive plural Ğ¿Ğ¾Ğ´Ğ¾ÌĞ²)

  1. hearth, hearthstone
  2. floor

Ñ - Wiktionary

Russian

Etymology 1

Pronunciation

  • IPA(key): [s]
  • Audio
    		(file)

Letter

Ñ â€¢ (s) (lower case, upper case Ğ¡)

  1. The nineteenth letter of the Russian Cyrillic alphabet. Its name is ÑÑ (es) and it has the sound of English s. It is preceded by Ğ  (R) and followed by Ğ¢ (T).

Etymology 2

From Proto-Slavic *sÑŠ(n), from Proto-Indo-European *á¸±om.

Pronunciation

  • IPA(key): [s]
  • Audio
    		(file)

Preposition

Ñ â€¢ (s)

  1. with (+ instrumental case)
    Ñ (Ğ¼Ğ¾Ğ¸ÌĞ¼) Ğ±Ñ€Ğ°ÌÑ‚Ğ¾Ğ¼ â€• s (moÃ­m) brÃ¡tom â€• with (my) brother
    Ñ (Ğ¼Ğ¾ĞµÌĞ¹) ÑĞµÑÑ‚Ñ€Ğ¾ÌĞ¹ â€• s (mojÃ©j) sestrÃ³j â€• with (my) sister
    ÑĞ¾ Ğ²ÑĞµÌĞ¼Ğ¸ â€• so vsÃ©mi â€• with everybody
    ÑĞ¾ Ğ¼Ğ½Ğ¾Ğ¹ â€• so mnoj â€• with me
    Ñ Ñ‚Ğ¾Ğ±Ğ¾ÌĞ¹ â€• s tobÃ³j â€• with you
  2. from, off, from off, from below (with abstract nouns; nouns entailing a flat, open area; and special exceptions) (+ genitive case)
    Ñ Ğ¿Ğ¾ÌÑ‡Ñ‚Ñ‹ â€• s pÃ³Äty â€• from the post office
    Ñ Ğ¿Ğ¾ÌĞ»Ñ â€• s pÃ³lja â€• from the field
    Ñ Ñ€Ğ°Ğ±Ğ¾ÌÑ‚Ñ‹ â€• s rabÃ³ty â€• from work
    ÑĞ¾ ÑÑ‚Ğ¾Ğ»Ğ°Ì â€• so stolÃ¡ â€• off the table
    ÑĞ´Ñ‘Ñ€Ğ½ÑƒÑ‚ÑŒ ÑĞºĞ°ÌÑ‚ĞµÑ€Ñ‚ÑŒ ÑĞ¾ ÑÑ‚Ğ¾Ğ»Ğ°Ì â€• sdjÃ³rnutÊ¹ skÃ¡tertÊ¹ so stolÃ¡ â€• to pull the cloth off the table
    Ñ Ğ½Ğ°Ñ‡Ğ°ÌĞ»Ğ° Ğ´Ğ¾ ĞºĞ¾Ğ½Ñ†Ğ°Ì â€• s naÄÃ¡la do koncÃ¡ â€• from beginning to end
  3. because of, since (expressing a cause of motivation) (+ genitive case)
    Ñ Ğ¸ÑĞ¿ÑƒÌĞ³Ğ° â€• s ispÃºga â€• due to being frightened
  4. for, about (indefinite time or number) (+ accusative case)
  5. (for indicating a duration of time; used in two forms: Ñ +genitive Ğ¿Ğ¾ +accusative and Ñ +genitive Ğ´Ğ¾ +genitive)
    Ğ ĞµĞ¼Ğ¾ÌĞ½Ñ‚ Ğ³Ğ»Ğ°ÌĞ²Ğ½Ğ¾Ğ³Ğ¾ Ğ·Ğ´Ğ°ÌĞ½Ğ¸Ñ Ğ±ÑƒÌĞ´ĞµÑ‚ Ğ¿Ñ€Ğ¾Ğ²Ğ¾Ğ´Ğ¸ÌÑ‚ÑŒÑÑ Ñ Ğ´Ğ²Ğ°ÌĞ´Ñ†Ğ°Ñ‚ÑŒ Ğ¿ÑÌÑ‚Ğ¾Ğ³Ğ¾ ÑĞ½Ğ²Ğ°Ñ€ÑÌ Ğ¿Ğ¾ ÑĞµĞ´ÑŒĞ¼Ğ¾ÌĞµ Ñ„ĞµĞ²Ñ€Ğ°Ğ»ÑÌ
    RemÃ³nt glÃ¡vnovo zdÃ¡nija bÃºdet provodÃ­tÊ¹sja s dvÃ¡dcatÊ¹ pjÃ¡tovo janvarjÃ¡ po sedÊ¹mÃ³je fevraljÃ¡
    The renovation of the main building will be conducted from January 25th to February 7th.
  6. (for time expressions)
    Ñ ĞºĞ°ÌĞ¶Ğ´Ñ‹Ğ¼ Ğ³Ğ¾ÌĞ´Ğ¾Ğ¼ â€• s kÃ¡Å¾dym gÃ³dom â€• from year to year, year by year, year after year
Usage notes
  • ÑĞ¾ (so) is used before words with certain awkward consonant clusters such as Ğ¼Ğ½ (mn), Ğ²Ñ (vs), and ÑĞ½ (sn).
  • A noun phrase with the preposition Ñ (s) or ÑĞ¾ (so) and an abstract noun declined with the instrumental case can show adverb-like qualities. The most notable ones are below:
    • Ñ Ğ²Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ¼Ğ°ÌĞ½Ğ¸ĞµĞ¼ (s vnimÃ¡nijem)
    • Ñ Ñ‚Ñ€ÑƒĞ´Ğ¾ÌĞ¼ (s trudÃ³m)
    • ÑĞ¾ ÑĞºÑ€Ğ¸ÌĞ¿Ğ¾Ğ¼ (so skrÃ­pom)
    • Ñ ÑƒĞ´Ğ¾Ğ²Ğ¾ÌĞ»ÑŒÑÑ‚Ğ²Ğ¸ĞµĞ¼ (s udovÃ³lÊ¹stvijem)
    • ÑĞ¾Ğ²ÑĞµÌĞ¼ (sovsÃ©m)
Related terms
  • Ğ»Ğ¸Ñ†Ğ¾ÌĞ¼ Ğº Ğ»Ğ¸Ñ†ÑƒÌ Ñ (licÃ³m k licÃº s)

Etymology 3

Abbreviation of ÑĞ°Ğ½Ñ‚Ğ¸- (santi-).

Pronunciation

  • IPA(key): [sÉ™nÊ²tÊ²Éª]Â (phonetic respelling: ÑĞ°Ğ½Ñ‚Ğ¸-)

Prefix

Ñ â€¢ (s)

  1. centi- (0.01)
References


  1. (+ instrumental case) with, together with, along with
    Ñ€Ğ°Ğ´Ğ¸Ñ‚Ğ¸ Ñ Ğ½ĞµĞºĞ¸Ğ¼ â€• to work with somebody
    ÑĞ²Ğ°Ñ’Ğ°Ñ‚Ğ¸ ÑĞµ Ñ Ğ½ĞµĞºĞ¸Ğ¼ â€• to quarrel with somebody
    Ñ€Ğ°Ñ‚Ğ¾Ğ²Ğ°Ñ‚Ğ¸ Ñ Ğ½ĞµĞºĞ¸Ğ¼ â€• to wage war with somebody
    Ğ´(Ñ˜)ĞµĞ²Ğ¾Ñ˜ĞºĞ° Ñ Ğ¿Ğ»Ğ°Ğ²Ğ¾Ğ¼ ĞºĞ¾ÑĞ¾Ğ¼ â€• a girl with blonde hair
    Ñ Ğ³Ğ¾Ğ´Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ°Ğ¼Ğ° Ğ´Ğ¾Ğ»Ğ°Ğ·Ğ¸ Ğ¼ÑƒĞ´Ñ€Ğ¾ÑÑ‚ â€• with age comes wisdom
    Ñ Ñ™ÑƒĞ±Ğ°Ğ²Ñ™Ñƒ â€• with love
  2. (+ instrumental case) miscellaneous prepositional senses in various phrases
    Ğ¨Ñ‚Ğ°/ÑˆÑ‚Ğ¾ Ñ˜Ğµ Ñ Ñ‚Ğ¾Ğ±Ğ¾Ğ¼? â€• What's wrong with you?
    Ñ Ğ²Ñ€ĞµĞ¼ĞµĞ½Ğ¾Ğ¼ â€• in time
    Ğ¿Ğ¾Ğ·Ğ´Ñ€Ğ°Ğ²Ğ¸Ñ‚Ğ¸ ÑĞµ Ñ˜ĞµĞ´Ğ½Ğ¾ Ñ Ğ´Ñ€ÑƒĞ³Ğ¸Ğ¼ â€• part ways with each other
  3. (+ genitive case) from, off
    Ğ¿Ğ°Ğ¾ ÑĞ°Ğ¼ ÑĞ° ÑÑ‚Ğ°Ğ±Ğ»Ğ° â€• I fell from the tree
    Ñ Ğ´Ñ€ÑƒĞ³Ğµ ÑÑ‚Ñ€Ğ°Ğ½Ğµ â€• on the other side
    ÑĞ° Ğ·Ğ°Ğ¿Ğ°Ğ´Ğ° â€• from the west
    Ñ Ğ»ĞµÑ’Ğ° â€• from the back
    Ğ¿Ñ€Ğ¾Ğ¼Ğ°Ñ‚Ñ€Ğ°Ñ‚Ğ¸ Ñ Ğ¿Ñ€Ğ¾Ğ·Ğ¾Ñ€Ğ° â€• to observe from the window
    Ñ™ÑƒĞ´Ğ¸ Ñ Ğ¿Ğ»Ğ°Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ½Ğµ â€• people from the mountain
  4. (proscribed) (+ genitive case) because of (= Ğ¸Ğ·, Ğ·Ğ±Ğ¾ÌĞ³)
    Ñ Ñ‚Ğ¾Ğ³ Ñ€Ğ°Ğ·Ğ»Ğ¾Ğ³Ğ° â€• for that reason
Usage notes

Ñ takes the alternative form ÑĞ° in the following environments:

  • before the sibilants /s, Å¡, z, Å¾/:
    ÑĞ° ÑÑ‚Ñ€Ğ°ÌĞ½ĞµÌ„
    aside
    ÑĞ° ÑˆĞºĞ¾Ì‘Ğ»Ğ¾Ì„Ğ¼
    with school
    ÑĞ° Ğ·ÑƒÌ‘Ğ±Ğ¾Ğ¼
    with the tooth
    ÑĞ° Ğ¶Ğ¸Ğ²Ğ¾Ì€Ñ‚Ğ¾Ğ¼
    with life
  • before consonant clusters where the second consonant is /s, Å¡, z/:
    {{ux|sh|sc=Cyrl|ÑĞ° Ğ¿ÑĞ¾ÌĞ¼|with the dog
    ÑĞ° Ğ¿ÑˆÑĞ½Ğ¸Ñ†Ğ¾Ì„Ğ¼
    with wheat
    {{ux|sh|sc=Cyrl|ÑĞ° Ñ€ÌĞ·Ğ°Ì„ÑšĞµĞ¼|with neighing
  • before the instrumental form of the first-person pronoun Ñ˜Ğ°Ì‘ (â€œIâ€)
    {{ux|sh|sc=Cyrl|ÑĞ° Ğ¼Ğ½Ğ¾Ì‘Ğ¼|with me

Etymology 3

Alternative forms

  • Ñ.

Abbreviation

Ñ (Roman spelling s)

  1. (grammar) neuter gender (ÑÑ€ĞµĞ´ÑšĞ¸ Ñ€Ğ¾Ğ´)

Ñ‚Ğ¸Ñ…Ğ¾ - Wiktionary

  • IPA(key): [ËˆtÊ²ixÉ™]

Adverb

Ñ‚Ğ¸ÌÑ…Ğ¾ â€¢ (tÃ­xo) (comparative (Ğ¿Ğ¾)Ñ‚Ğ¸ÌÑˆĞµ)

  2. quietly, calmly, peacefully
  3. slowly

ê°€ - Wiktionary

Korean

Etymology 1

ê°€ê°ê°‚ê°ƒê°„ê°…ê°†
ê°‡ê°ˆê°‰ê°Šê°‹ê°Œê°
ê°ê°ê°ê°‘ê°’ê°“ê°”
ê°•ê°–ê°—ê°˜ê°™ê°šê°›
â†’ ê°œ

Pronunciation

  • Audio
    		(file)
  • IPA(key)[kaÌ ]
  • Phonetic Hangul[ê°€]
Revised Romanization? ga
Revised Romanization (translit.)? ga
McCuneâ€“Reischauer? ka
Yale Romanization? ka

Symbol

ê°€ â€¢ (ga)

  1. A Hangul syllabic block made up of ã„± and ã…. The first syllable of the hangul writing system. Often used to mark the first item of a list or sub-list.

Etymology 2

First attested in the Yongbi eocheonga (é¾é£›å¾¡å¤©æ­Œ / ìš©ë¹„ì–´ì²œê°€), 1447, as Middle Korean á„€á†á†º (kos).

Pronunciation

  • IPA(key)[kaÌ Ë]
  • Phonetic Hangul[ê°€]
Revised Romanization? ga
Revised Romanization (translit.)? ga
McCuneâ€“Reischauer? ka
Yale Romanization? kÄ

Noun

ê°€ â€¢ (ga)

  1. (often as a suffix) bound, edge, end, margin, rim, side, verge, brink
Synonyms
  • (bound, edge, end): ê°€ì¥ìë¦¬ (gajangjari), ë³€ë‘ë¦¬ (byeonduri), ì–¸ì €ë¦¬ (eonjeori)
Antonyms
  • (bound, edge, end): ì† (sok, â€œinside, interiorâ€), ì•ˆ (an, â€œinside, interiorâ€), ì•Œë§¹ì´ (almaeng-i, â€œcoreâ€)
Derived terms
Terms derived from ê°€ (ga)
  • ê°€ì—†ë‹¤ (ga-eopda, â€œto be boundless, limitlessâ€)
  • ê°•ê°€ (æ±Ÿâ€”, gangga, â€œriversideâ€)
  • ê¸¸ê°€ (gilga, â€œroadsideâ€)
  • ë‚œë¡œê°€ (ç…–çˆâ€”, nalloga, â€œfiresideâ€)
  • ë¬¼ê°€ (mulga, â€œshoreâ€)
  • ë°”ë‹·ê°€ (badatga, â€œseasideâ€)
  • ì…ê°€ (ipga, â€œlipsâ€)
Related terms
  • ê°€ì£½ (gajuk, â€œhide, skin, leatherâ€)
  • ê±°ì£½ (geojuk, â€œoutside, exterior, surfaceâ€)
  • ê²‰ (geot, â€œoutside, exterior, surfaceâ€)

Etymology 3

Unknown. It was not attested in texts from the 15th century, and its first attestation has been variously placed at 1572 CE[1] or mid-17th century[2]. It was initially a subject particle, of limited distribution and used in a complementary manner to â€”ì´ (i). The development of its usage is as follows:[3]

  1. Since the mid-17th century: used after nouns ending in -i or -y,
    e.g. pwuli-ka ("mouth"), nay-ka ("scent"), poy-ka ("boat");
  2. Since the mid-18th century: used after nouns ending in vowels/semivowels other than -i,
    e.g. ca-ka ("one who"), soyngswo-ka, nwongso-ka ("farm work");
  3. During the end of the 18th century: used briefly in the form of double particle -i/yka after nouns ending in vowels/semivowels other than -i,
    e.g. to-yka ("road"), inkwu-yka ("population"), nwongso-yka ("farm work").

Various theories exist regarding its origin:

  1. Developed from the interrogative particle â€”ê°€ (ga);[4]
  2. Developed from the vocative case particle â€”í•˜ (ha)/â€”ì•„ (a);[5]
  3. Developed from the connective ending â€”ë‹¤ê°€ (daga);[6]
  4. Developed from the verb ê°€â€” (ga-, â€œto goâ€);[7]
  5. Borrowed from the Japanese nominative particle ãŒ (ga).[8]

Pronunciation

  • Audio
    		(file)
  • IPA(key)[kaÌ ]
  • Phonetic Hangul[ê°€]
Revised Romanization? ga
Revised Romanization (translit.)? ga
McCuneâ€“Reischauer? ka
Yale Romanization? ka

Particle

ê°€ â€¢ (ga)

  1. Indicates the subject of a sentence.
  2. Indicates the subjective complement of a sentence, usually used with ë˜ë‹¤ (doeda, â€œbecomeâ€) or ì•„ë‹ˆë‹¤ (anida, â€œbe notâ€).
Usage notes
  • ê°€ (ga) indicates the subject of the verb in the sentence, as opposed to the object, which *ë¥¼ (reul) indicates. See also ëŠ” (neun), which indicates the topic of the sentence.
  • ê°€ (ga) is used only after words ending with a vowel. After words ending with a consonant, ì´ (i) is used instead.
Synonyms
  • ì´ (i)
See also
  • ì€ (eun)
  • ëŠ” (neun)
  • ì„ (eul)
  • ë¥¼ (reul)

Etymology 4

Korean reading of various Chinese characters

Etymology 5

Infinitive of ê°€ë‹¤ (gada, â€œto goâ€).

Pronunciation

  • Audio
    		(file)
  • IPA(key)[kaÌ ]
  • Phonetic Hangul[ê°€]
Revised Romanization? ga
Revised Romanization (translit.)? ga
McCuneâ€“Reischauer? ka
Yale Romanization? ka

Verb

ê°€ â€¢ (ga) (infinitive of ê°€ë‹¤)

  1. connective form of ê°€ë‹¤ (gada, â€œto goâ€): because of going, upon going.
  2. informal form of ê°€ë‹¤ (gada, â€œto goâ€): go (indicative/interrogative/imperative), let's go
Synonyms
  • (infinitive of ê°€ë‹¤, because of going, upon going): ê°€ì„œ (gaseo)

Etymology 6

Noun

ê°€ â€¢ (ga)

  1. la (musical note)

  • Sino-Korean words

ê°„ - Wiktionary

Korean

Etymology 1

ê°€ê°ê°‚ê°ƒê°„ê°…ê°†
ê°‡ê°ˆê°‰ê°Šê°‹ê°Œê°
ê°ê°ê°ê°‘ê°’ê°“ê°”
ê°•ê°–ê°—ê°˜ê°™ê°šê°›
â†’ ê°œ

Syllable

ê°„ â€¢ (gan)

  1. A Hangul syllabic block made up of ã„±, ã…, and ã„´.

Etymology 2

From é–“.

Suffix

â€”ê°„ â€¢ (-gan) (hanja é–“)

  1. (time) for
  2. (place) between

Etymology 3

Noun

ê°„ â€¢ (gan)

  1. salty seasonings
Derived terms
  • ê°„ì¥ (ganjang)

Etymology 4

Noun

ê°„ â€¢ (gan) (hanja è‚)

  1. (abbreviation of ê°„ì¥) liver
    • ê°„ì€ ìš°ë¦¬ ëª¸ì—ì„œ ê°€ì¥ ì¤‘ìš”í•œ ê¸°ê´€ ì¤‘ì˜ í•˜ë‚˜ì´ë‹¤.
      Ganeun uri momeseo gajang jung-yohan gigwan jung-ui hanaida.
      The liver is one of the most important organs in our body.

Etymology 5

Korean reading of various Chinese characters.

Syllable

ê°„ (gan)

  • ê°„ê°„ì´ (é–“é–“ì´, gan-gani): often, occasionally
  • ê°„ê²© (é–“éš”, gan-gyeok): gap, interval, distance, duration
  • ê°„ê²° (ç°¡æ½”, gan-gyeol): conciseness
  • ê°„ê³„ (å¥¸è¨ˆ, gan-gye): evil design
  • ê°„ê³¼ (çœ‹é, gan-gwa): overlooking
  • ê°„êµ (å¥¸å·§, gan-gyo): cunningness
  • ê°„ê·¹ (é–“éš™, gan-geuk): gap
  1. This term needs a translation to English. Please help out and add a translation, then remove the text {{rfdef}}.

Etymology 1

ê°€ê°ê°‚ê°ƒê°„ê°…ê°†

ê² - Wiktionary

Korean

Etymology 1

ê±°ê±±ê±²ê±³ê±´ê±µê±¶
ê±·ê±¸ê±¹ê±ºê±»ê±¼ê±½
ê±¾ê±¿ê²€ê²ê²‚ê²ƒê²„
ê²…ê²†ê²‡ê²ˆê²‰ê²Šê²‹
ê±” â†â†’ ê²Œ

Syllable

ê² â€¢ (geop)

  1. A Hangul syllabic block made up of ã„±, ã…“, and ã…‚.

Etymology 2

Sino-Korean word from æ€¯ (â€œfearâ€)

Pronunciation

  • IPA(key)[kÊŒÌ¹pÌš]
  • Phonetic Hangul[ê²]
Revised Romanization? geop
Revised Romanization (translit.)? geob
McCuneâ€“Reischauer? kÅp
Yale Romanization? kep

Noun

ê² â€¢ (geop)

  1. fear, dread, timidity

Synonyms

  • ë¬´ì„œì›€ (museoum), ë‘ë ¤ì›€ (duryeoum), ê³µí¬ (ææ€–, gongpo)
  • ê²ëŒ€ê°€ë¦¬ (geopdaegari) (slang)

Derived terms

  • ê²ì¥ì´ (geopjang-i), ê²ìŸì´ (geopjaeng-i, â€œcowardâ€)

ê²ƒ - Wiktionary

Korean

Pronunciation

  • IPA(key)[kÊŒÌ¹tÌš]
  • Phonetic Hangul[ê±·]
Revised Romanization? geot
Revised Romanization (translit.)? geos
McCuneâ€“Reischauer? kÅt
Yale Romanization? kes
Audio
(file)

Etymology 1

ê±°ê±±ê±²ê±³ê±´ê±µê±¶
ê±·ê±¸ê±¹ê±ºê±»ê±¼ê±½
ê±¾ê±¿ê²€ê²ê²‚ê²ƒê²„
ê²…ê²†ê²‡ê²ˆê²‰ê²Šê²‹
ê±” â†â†’ ê²Œ

Syllable

ê²ƒ â€¢ (geot)

  1. A Hangul syllabic block made up of ã„±, ã…“, and ã…….

Etymology 2

First attested in the Seokbo sangjeol (é‡‹è­œè©³ç¯€ / ì„ë³´ìƒì ˆ), 1447, as Middle Korean ê²ƒ. Compare Japanese äº‹ (koto, â€œabstract thingâ€), ç¨® (kusa, â€œsort, kind; causeâ€).

Noun

ê²ƒ â€¢ (geot)

  1. A thing; an object, one (impersonal pronoun)
    ë¹„ì‹¼ ê²ƒ â€• bissan geot â€• an expensive thing; something expensive; an (the) expensive one
    ì´ ì„¸ìƒì€ ìš°ë¦¬ë“¤ì˜ ê²ƒì´ì—ˆì§€ë§Œ, ì´ì œëŠ” ë„ˆí¬ë“¤ì˜ ê²ƒì´ë‹¤.
    I sesang-eun urideurui geosieotjiman, ijeneun neohuideurui geosida.
    This world was ours, but now itâ€™s yours.
  2. (used to create noun phrases) what; the thing which
    ë‚´ê°€ ì›í•˜ëŠ” ê²ƒ
    naega wonhaneun geot
    what I want
Derived terms
  • ê±° (geo) (contraction)
  • ê²Œ (ge) (contraction of ê²ƒì´ (geosi))
  • ê±¸ (geol) (contraction of ê²ƒì„ (geoseul))
  • ê±´ (geon) (contraction of ê²ƒì€ (geoseun))

See also

  • ê³³ (got, â€œplaceâ€)
  • ê³§ (got, â€œsoon, immediatelyâ€)
  • ê°€ (ga, â€œedge, sideâ€)

ê²Œ - Wiktionary

Korean

Pronunciation

  • IPA(key)[keÌË]
  • Phonetic Hangul[ê²Œ]
Revised Romanization? ge
Revised Romanization (translit.)? ge
McCuneâ€“Reischauer? ke
Yale Romanization? kÄ“y

Etymology 1

ê²Œê²ê²ê²ê²ê²‘ê²’
ê²“ê²”ê²•ê²–ê²—ê²˜ê²™
ê²šê²›ê²œê²ê²ê²Ÿê² 
ê²¡ê²¢ê²£ê²¤ê²¥ê²¦ê²§
ê±° â†â†’ ê²¨

Syllable

ê²Œ â€¢ (ge)

  1. A Hangul syllabic block made up of ã„± and ã…”.

Etymology 2

Particle

ê²Œ â€¢ (ge)

  1. A shortened form of the dative particle ì—ê²Œ (ege); to, (for, by)
Usage notes
  • Like ì—ê²Œ (ege), ê²Œ (ge) is only used only with nouns denoting animate objects (usually people or animals). This shortened form is only used with a few common words that end in a vowel, such as ë‚´ (nae, â€œIâ€) (alternate form), ë„¤ (ne, â€œyouâ€) (alternate form), or ì œ (je, â€œIâ€) (humble, alternate form).
    ë‚´ê²Œ ì‚¬ë‘ì„ ì£¼ì„¸ìš”.
    Naege sarang-eul juseyo.
    Please give me love.
  • For nouns denoting inanimate objects, ì— (e) is used instead.

Etymology 3

Contraction of ê±°ì´.

Noun

ê²Œ â€¢ (ge)

  1. thing (nominative case)
Synonyms
  • ê²ƒì´ (geosi)

Etymology 4

Contraction of ê±°ê¸°. First attested in the Seokbo sangjeol (é‡‹è­œè©³ç¯€ / ì„ë³´ìƒì ˆ), 1447, as Middle Korean ê·¸á…Œá…¥ê¸” (ku.nge.kuy). Later shortened into ê·¸á…Œá…¦ (Yale: Ku.ngey)

Pronoun

ê²Œ â€¢ (ge)

  1. there
    ê²Œ ëˆ„êµ¬ ìˆëŠëƒ?
    Ge nugu inneunya?
    Is someone there?
See also
Korean demonstratives edit

Pronoun Human ì´ì´ ê·¸ì´ ì €ì´
ì´ë¶„ ê·¸ë¶„ ì €ë¶„
ì´ì ê·¸ì ì €ì
ì´ë†ˆ ê·¸ë†ˆ ì €ë†ˆ
ì´ë…„ ê·¸ë…„ ì €ë…„
ì–˜ ê±” ìŸ¤

ì´ê²ƒ ê·¸ê²ƒ ì €ê²ƒ ì–´ëŠ ê²ƒ
ì´ê±° ê·¸ê±° ì €ê±° ì–´ëŠ ê±°

ì´ë¦¬í•˜ë‹¤ ê·¸ë¦¬í•˜ë‹¤ ì €ë¦¬í•˜ë‹¤ ì–´ì°Œí•˜ë‹¤
Adjective ì´ë ‡ë‹¤ ê·¸ë ‡ë‹¤ ì €ë ‡ë‹¤ ì–´ë–»ë‹¤
ì´ëŸ¬í•˜ë‹¤ ê·¸ëŸ¬í•˜ë‹¤ ì €ëŸ¬í•˜ë‹¤ ì–´ë– í•˜ë‹¤
Adverb ì´ë¦¬ ê·¸ë¦¬ ì €ë¦¬ ì–´ì°Œ
ì´ë ‡ê²Œ ê·¸ë ‡ê²Œ ì €ë ‡ê²Œ ì–´ë–»ê²Œ
ì´ë§Œí¼ ê·¸ë§Œí¼ ì €ë§Œí¼

Etymology 5

First attested in the Gugeupbang eonhae (æ•‘æ€¥æ–¹è«ºè§£ / êµ¬ê¸‰ë°©ì–¸í•´), 1466, as Middle Korean ê²Œ (key). Words with similar shapes exist in the region, compare Jeju ê¹…ì´ (ging-i), Japanese èŸ¹ (kani), Proto-Sino-Tibetan d-k(j)aËj ~ d-k(j)aËn (â€œcrabâ€), Old Chinese èŸ¹ (OC *É¡reËÊ”).

Noun

ê²Œ â€¢ (ge)

  1. crab

Related terms

  • ê²Œì¥ (gejang)

Etymology 6

First attested in the Worin cheongangjigok (æœˆå°åƒæ±Ÿä¹‹æ›² / ì›”ì¸ì²œê°•ì§€ê³¡), 1449, as Middle Korean ê¸” (kuy).

Suffix

â€”ê²Œ â€¢ (-ge)

  1. an adverbial suffix
    í•˜ëŠ˜ì´ ë¶‰ê²Œ ë¬¼ë“¤ì—ˆë‹¤.
    Haneuri bulge muldeureotda.
    The sky turned red.
  2. so that; to the extent where
    ë¬¼ ë§ˆì‹œê²Œ ì»µ ì¢€.
    Mul masige keop jom.
    A cup please, so I can have water.
    ê·¸ì˜ ëª¸ì— ê¼­ ë§ê²Œ ë§ì¶˜ ì˜·ì´ ë°°ë‹¬ë˜ì–´ ì™”ë‹¤.
    Geuui mome kkok matge matchun osi baedaldoeeo watda.
    The clothes, which were made to fit him perfectly, were delivered.
Usage notes

The suffix ê²Œ (ge) is directly appended to the stem of a verb, an adjective, or ì´ë‹¤ (ida), and if the stem ends in the consonant ã„¹ (l), it does not drop out.

When used right before í•˜ë‹¤ (hada, â€œto doâ€), it may make the preceding verb causative, and it may imply a slight passiveness if right before ë˜ë‹¤ (doeda, â€œto becomeâ€).

ë‚˜ì¤‘ì— ë˜ ë§Œë‚˜ê²Œ ë˜ë©´ ë” ë§›ë‚œ ê±° ë¨¹ê²Œ í•´ ì¤„ê²Œ.
Najung-e tto mannage doemyeon deo mannan geo meokge hae julge.
I'll let you eat more yummy things when we meet again someday.
See also
  • ê²Œë” (gekkeum)

Etymology 7

Of native Korean origin.

Suffix

â€”ê²Œ â€¢ (-ge)

  1. a familiar style imperative suffix
    ë§í•˜ê²Œ. ê·¸ë‚  ìë„¤ëŠ” ë­˜ í•˜ê³  ìˆì—ˆë‚˜?
    Malhage. Geunal janeneun mwol hago isseonna?
    Please tell me. What were you doing that day?
Usage notes

The suffix ê²Œ (ge) is directly attached to the stem of a verb, and if the stem ends in the consonant ã„¹ (l), it does not drop out.

See also
  • ê²Œë‚˜ (gena)

Etymology 8

Of native Korean origin.

Suffix

â€”ê²Œ â€¢ (-ge)

  1. Are you going to...?
    ì§€ê¸ˆ ê°€ê²Œ? ë„ˆë¬´ ì´ë¥´ì§€ ì•Šì•„?
    Jigeum gage? Neomu ireuji ana?
    Are you going now? Isn't it too early?
  2. Guess what/if...!
    ëˆ„êµ¬ê²Œ?
    Nuguge?
    Guess who!
  3. used to sarcastically deny the possibility of being true
    ë§ë§Œ í•˜ë©´ ë‹¤ ë˜ê²Œ?
    Malman hamyeon da doege?
    Will it be all done just by saying?
    ë„¤ê°€ ê²€ì‚¬ë©´ ë‚œ íŒì‚¬ê²Œ? ì°¨ë¼ë¦¬ ëŒ€í†µë ¹ì´ë¼ê³  í•´ë¼!
    Nega geomsamyeon nan pansage? Charari daetongnyeong-irago haera!
    Were you to be the prosecutor, then would I be the judge? More plausible if you have said the president!
Usage notes

The suffix ê²Œ (ge) is directly appended to the stem of a verb, an adjective, or ì´ë‹¤ (ida, â€œto beâ€), and if the stem ends in the consonant ã„¹ (l), it does not drop out.

See also
  • ë ¤ê³  (ryeogo)

Etymology 9

Reading of various Chinese characters.

Syllable

ê²Œ (ge)

  1. åˆ, åŸ, æ†©, æ², æ­, ç¢£

ê³  - Wiktionary

Korean

Etymology 1

ê³ ê³¡ê³¢ê³£ê³¤ê³¥ê³¦
ê³§ê³¨ê³©ê³ªê³«ê³¬ê³­
ê³®ê³¯ê³°ê³±ê³²ê³³ê³´
ê³µê³¶ê³·ê³¸ê³¹ê³ºê³»
ê³„ â†â†’ ê³¼

Syllable

ê³  â€¢ (go)

  1. A Hangul syllabic block made up of ã„± and ã…—.

Etymology 2

Suffix

â€”ê³  â€¢ (-go)

  1. and then
    In this sense, usually a single subject governs two clauses. ê³  (go) is attached to the stem of the final verb of the first clause.
  2. and
    In this sense, usually two clauses with different subjects express coordinated actions or descriptions. ê³  (go) is attached to the stem of the final verb of the first clause.
    • ë‚˜ëŠ” í•œêµ­ì–´ë¥¼ ê³µë¶€í•˜ê³ , ê·¸ëŠ” ì˜ì–´ë¥¼ ê³µë¶€í•´ìš”.
      Naneun hangugeoreul gongbuhago, geuneun yeong-eoreul gongbuhaeyo.
      I am studying Korean, and he is studying English.
  3. (in the process of) -ing
    In this sense, ê³  (go) is attached to the stem of the verb and is followed by ìˆë‹¤ (itda, â€œto existâ€).
    • ì €ëŠ” í•œêµ­ë§ì„ ê³µë¶€í•˜ê³  ìˆìŠµë‹ˆë‹¤.
      Jeoneun han-gungmareul gongbuhago itseumnida.
      I am (in the process of) studying Korean.
  4. a suffix used to join a main verb/adjective and its auxiliary verb/adjective.
    • í•˜ê³  ì‹¶ë‹¤ (hago sipda, â€œto want to doâ€)
    • í•˜ê³  ë‚˜ë‹¤ (hago nada, â€œto finish doingâ€)
    • í•˜ê³  ë“¤ë‹¤ (hago deulda, â€œto do fiercelyâ€)
    • í•˜ê³  ë³´ë‹¤ (hago boda, â€œto do without much thinkingâ€)
    • í•˜ê³  ë§ë‹¤ (hago malda, â€œto end up doing; to finally succeed to doâ€)

Etymology 3

Cognate with -ë¼ê³  (rago) used for making a direct quotation and also for an indirect quotation ending in ì´ë‹¤ (ida) or ì•„ë‹ˆë‹¤ (anida).

Suffix

â€”ê³  â€¢ (-go)

  1. that (marking an indirect quotation)
Usage notes

In the indirect quotation sense, -ê³  (go) is attached to a í•´ë¼ì²´ (haerache, â€œplainâ€) form of the quoted verb and is followed by a clause ending in a verb related to speech or í•˜ë‹¤ (hada, â€œto doâ€).

  • If -ê³  (go) is attached to a plain indicative form of the verb, the following í•˜ë‹¤ (hada) may translate as a form of â€œto say that...â€.
  • If -ê³  (go) is attached to a plain interrogative form (-ëƒ (nya)/ëŠëƒ (neunya)), the following í•˜ë‹¤ (hada) may translate as a form of â€œto ask [whether, who, what, when, which, how, why]...â€.
  • If -ê³  (go) is attached to a plain imperative form (-ë¼ (ra)), the following í•˜ë‹¤ (hada) may translate as a form of â€œto command to...â€.
  • If -ê³  (go) is attached to a plain proposative form (-ì (ja)), the following í•˜ë‹¤ (hada) may translate as a form of â€œto suggest to...â€.

In standard Korean grammar, combined suffixes such as -ë‹¤ê³ , -ëƒê³ , -ë¼ê³ , -ìê³  are analyzed as a whole to be individual ones, therefore listed in dictionary respectively.

Etymology 4

Reading of various Chinese characters

Determiner

ê³  â€¢ (go) (hanja æ•…)

  1. late
  2. deceased

Syllable

ê³  â€¢ (go)

  1. ä¼°, ä¾¤, å‡…, åˆ³, å¤, å©, å¿, å‘Š, å‘±, å’, å’•, åš³, å›º, å¡™, å§‘, å­¤, å°», åº«, æ‹·, æ”·, æ•…, æ•², æš , æ², æ¯, æ ², æ§€, æ§, æ§¹, æ«œ, æ²½, ç‰¯, ç—¼, çš‹, çš, ç›¬, ç¾, ç½, ç¨, ç¨¿, ç®, ç¯™, ç³•, ç½Ÿ, ç¾”, ç¾–, ç¿±, ç¿º, è€ƒ, è‚¡, èƒ¯, è„µ, è†, è‹¦, è‹½, è°, è—, è ±, è¢´, è§š, è©, èª¥, è³ˆ, è¾œ, éƒœ, é…¤, éˆ·, éŒ®, é›‡, é , é¡§, éª·, é«˜, é«™, é¯, é´£, é·±, é¼“
Retrieved from "https://en.wiktionary.org/w/index.php?title=ê³ &oldid=49532615"

ê·¸ - Wiktionary

Korean

Pronunciation

  • IPA(key)[kÉ¯]
  • Phonetic Hangul[ê·¸]
Revised Romanization? geu
Revised Romanization (translit.)? geu
McCuneâ€“Reischauer? kÅ­
Yale Romanization? ku

Etymology 1

ê·¸ê·¹ê·ºê·»ê·¼ê·½ê·¾
ê·¿ê¸€ê¸ê¸‚ê¸ƒê¸„ê¸…
ê¸†ê¸‡ê¸ˆê¸‰ê¸Šê¸‹ê¸Œ
ê¸ê¸ê¸ê¸ê¸‘ê¸’ê¸“
ê·œ â†â†’ ê¸”

Syllable

ê·¸ â€¢ (geu)

  1. A Hangul syllabic block made up of ã„± and ã…¡.

Etymology 2

Of native Korean origin.
(pronoun) introduced together with ê·¸ë…€ (geunyeo) by Kim Dong-in[1], probably calque of Japanese å½¼Â (ã‹ã‚Œ) (kare).

Determiner

ê·¸ â€¢ (geu)

  1. (demonstrative) that (of what has been already said or known)
    • ê·¸ ë‚¨ìëŠ” ì¼ë³¸ì¸ì…ë‹ˆê¹Œ ì•„ë‹ˆë©´ ì¤‘êµ­ì¸ì…ë‹ˆê¹Œ? ê·¸ëŠ” ì¤‘êµ­ì¸ì…ë‹ˆë‹¤.
      Geu namjaneun ilboninimnikka animyeon jungguginimnikka? geuneun jungguginimnida.
      Is that man Japanese or Chinese? - He is Chinese.
Usage notes

ê·¸ (geu) is used for items closer to the listener than to the speaker, and ì € (jeo) is used for items far from both the speaker and the listener

Derived terms
  • ê·¸ê²ƒ (geugeot, â€œthat thingâ€)
  • ê·¸ê³³ (geugot, â€œthat placeâ€)
  • ê·¸ë•Œ (geuttae, â€œthat momentâ€)
  • ê·¸ëŒ€ë¡œ (geudaero, â€œlike thatâ€)
  • ê·¸ë ‡ë‹¤ (geureota, â€œto be that wayâ€)
  • ê·¸ì´ (geu-i, â€œheâ€)
  • ê·¸ë†ˆ (geunom, â€œheâ€) (insulting)
  • ê·¸ë†ˆë“¤ (geunomdeul, â€œtheyâ€) (insulting)
  • ê·¸ë…„ (geunyeon, â€œsheâ€) (insulting)
See also
  • ì´ (i, â€œthisâ€)
  • ì € (jeo, â€œthatâ€)

Pronoun

ê·¸ â€¢ (geu)

  1. (demonstrative) that (of what has been already said or known) (see ê·¸ê²ƒ (geugeot, â€œthat thingâ€))
  2. (literary) he; she
    • ê·¸ëŠ” ì•„ë¬´ëŸ° ë§ë„ ì—†ì´ ê°€ë²„ë ¸ë‹¤.
      Geuneun amureon maldo eopsi gabeoryeotda.
      He left without saying anything.
Usage notes

ê·¸ë…€ (geunyeo, â€œsheâ€) is an explicitly feminine third-person pronoun.

Synonyms
  • (demonstrative, that): ì € (jeo)
Antonyms
  • (demonstrative, this): ì´ (i)
Derived terms
  • ê·¸ë…€ (geunyeo, â€œsheâ€)
  • ê·¸ë“¤ (geudeul, â€œtheyâ€)
  • ê·¸ë„¤ë“¤ (geunedeul, â€œtheyâ€)

See also

ê½ƒ - Wiktionary

Korean

Etymology

First attested in the Yongbi eocheonga (é¾é£›å¾¡å¤©æ­Œ / ìš©ë¹„ì–´ì²œê°€), 1447, as Middle Korean ê³¶ (koc). The change to a tense consonant initial occurred as this word ("flower") was frequently used as the second part of a compound noun denoting a specific flower (e.g. ì—°ê½ƒ (yeonkkot)), in which the connecting genitive -ã……- (-s-) formed a "-sk-" medial cluster with koc, which developed into "-kk-" in Modern Korean. This development in compound nouns was generalised to koc as well.[1]

Pronunciation

  • IPA(key)[kÍˆoÌtÌš]
  • Phonetic Hangul[ê¼³]
Revised Romanization? kkot
Revised Romanization (translit.)? kkoch
McCuneâ€“Reischauer? kkot
Yale Romanization? kkoch

Noun

ê½ƒ â€¢ (kkot)

  1. (botany) flower; flowering plant
    ê½ƒì´ í•€ë‹¤.
    Kkochi pinda.
    Flowers bloom.
    ê½ƒ í•œ ì†¡ì´
    kkot han song-i
    a flower / one flower
    ê½ƒ í•œ ë‹¤ë°œ
    kkot han dabal
    a bunch of flowers
  2. (figuratively) prime; central part; essence

Synonyms

  • í™” (èŠ±, hwa, â€œflowerâ€) (used only in compounds)

References

  1. ^ Ki-mun Yi, Ki-Moon Lee, S. Robert Ramsey. A History of the Korean Language. Cambridge University Press, 2011. â†’ISBN.
Retrieved from "https://en.wiktionary.org/w/index.php?title=ê½ƒ&oldid=48032800"

ë‚˜ - Wiktionary

Korean

Pronunciation

  • IPA(key)[naÌ ]
  • Phonetic Hangul[ë‚˜]
Revised Romanization? na
Revised Romanization (translit.)? na
McCuneâ€“Reischauer? na
Yale Romanization? na

Etymology 1

ë‚˜ë‚™ë‚šë‚›ë‚œë‚ë‚
ë‚Ÿë‚ ë‚¡ë‚¢ë‚£ë‚¤ë‚¥
ë‚¦ë‚§ë‚¨ë‚©ë‚ªë‚«ë‚¬
ë‚­ë‚®ë‚¯ë‚°ë‚±ë‚²ë‚³
ë¼ â†â†’ ë‚´

Syllable

ë‚˜ â€¢ (na)

  1. A Hangul syllabic block made up of ã„´ and ã….

Etymology 2

Probably cognate with Old Japanese å·± (na, â€œIâ€, first-person singular plain (non-polite) pronoun).

Pronoun

ë‚˜ â€¢ (na)

  1. I, the first-person singular plain (non-polite) pronoun
    ë„¤ê°€ ì•„ë‹ˆê³  ë‚˜ì•¼.
    Nega anigo naya.
    It's not you, it's me.
Alternative forms
  • ë‚´ (nae)
    • in the nominative case, ë‚´ê°€ (nae-ga)
    • short for the genitive case, ë‚˜ì˜ (na-ui)
Antonyms
  • ë„ˆ (neo): you
  • ë‚¨ (nam): anybody or somebody other than myself
Related terms
  • ë„ˆë‚˜ (neona): you and I
    • ë„ˆë‚˜ ì—†ì´ (neona eopsi): all of us (equally)
    • ë„ˆë‚˜ í•  ê²ƒ ì—†ì´ (neona hal geot eopsi): all of us, without discriminating you and me for example
See also
  • ìš°ë¦¬ (uri): we, our
  • ì € (jeo): the first person singular polite pronoun

Etymology 3

Of native Korean origin.

Particle

ë‚˜ â€¢ (na)

  1. just; at least
    í•˜ë˜ ê±°ë‚˜ í•˜ë ¨ë‹¤.
    Hadeon geona haryeonda.
    Gonna do just what I've been doing.
  2. or
    ì§„ì£¼ë‚˜ ì°½ì› ìª½ìœ¼ë¡œ ê°€ë ¤ë©´ ëª‡ ë²ˆ êµ­ë„ë¥¼ íƒ€ì•¼ í•˜ë‚˜ìš”?
    Jinjuna chang-won jjogeuro garyeomyeon myeot beon gukdoreul taya hanayo?
    What route should I take to get to Jinju or Changwon?
  3. no less than
    8kmë‚˜ ê±¸ì—ˆëŠ”ë°ë„ ê±°ì˜ ì§€ì¹˜ì§€ ì•Šì€ ê¸°ìƒ‰ì´ë‹¤.
    8kmna georeonneundedo geoui jichiji aneun gisaegida.
    He has walked 5 miles already, but still seems nearly untired.
  4. no matter which/who
    ëˆ„êµ¬ë‚˜ í•œë²ˆì¯¤ì€ ë„˜ì–´ì§ˆ ìˆ˜ ìˆì–´.
    Nuguna hanbeonjjeumeun neomeojil su isseo.
    It's fine. Everyone falls over once or twice.
  5. sb said ... (I'm suspicious or not interested, though)
    ìê¸°ëŠ” ëª°ëë‹¤ë‚˜, ë­ ê·¸ëŸ¬ë°.
    Jagineun mollatdana, mwo geureode.
    Well, maybe he said he didn't know? Something like that.
Usage notes

The particle ë‚˜ (na) is used after a vowel, whereas ì´ë‚˜ (ina) is used after a consonant.

Alternative forms
  • ì´ë‚˜ (ina)

Etymology 4

Of native Korean origin.

Suffix

â€”ë‚˜ â€¢ (-na)

  1. but
    ê´‘ì£¼Â·ì „ë‚¨ì§€ì—­ì€ ê³³ì— ë”°ë¼ êµ¬ë¦„ì´ ë§ì´ ë¼ê² ìœ¼ë‚˜ ëŒ€ì²´ë¡œ ë§‘ê² ìŠµë‹ˆë‹¤.
    GwangjuÂ·jeonnamjiyeogeun gose ttara gureumi mani kkigesseuna daechero malgetseumnida.
    Gwangju and Jeonnam region will be partly cloudy, but mostly clear.
  2. regardless whether
    ìˆìœ¼ë‚˜ ì—†ìœ¼ë‚˜ ë³„ ì°¨ì´ê°€ ì—†ë‹¤.
    Isseuna eopseuna byeol chaiga eopda.
    There's little difference whether there it is or not.
  3. (in the form of '-ë‚˜ -ã„´') very
    ê¸°ë‚˜ê¸´ ì—¬ì • ëì— ë§ˆì¹¨ë‚´ í•œêµ­ì— ë„ì°©í–ˆë‹¤.
    Ginagin yeojeong kkeute machimnae han-guge dochakhaetda.
    After the long journey, we finally arrived in Korea.
Usage notes

The suffix ë‚˜ (na) takes the sequential form of a verb, an adjective, or ì´ë‹¤ (ida, â€œto beâ€), and if the stem ends in the consonant ã„¹ (l), it drops out.

Etymology 5

Of native Korean origin.

Suffix

â€”ë‚˜ â€¢ (-na)

  1. a familiar style interrogative suffix
    ìë„¤ëŠ” ì „ê³µì„ ë¬´ì—‡ìœ¼ë¡œ ì •í–ˆë‚˜?
    Janeneun jeon-gong-eul mueoseuro jeonghaenna?
    What did you choose to major in?
    ì„œìš¸ì—­ì— ì–´ë–»ê²Œ ê°€ë‚˜ìš”?
    Seouryeoge eotteoke ganayo?
    How can I get to Seoul Station?
  2. (in the form of '-ë‚˜ í•˜ë‹¤/ì‹¶ë‹¤/ë³´ë‹¤') indicates the monologic question or inference
    ì˜ ì§€ë‚´ë‚˜ ì‹¶ì–´ì„œ ì „í™”í–ˆì§€.
    Jal jinaena sipeoseo jeonhwahaetji.
    I called you to see if you fare well.
    ê·¸ë“¤ë„ ë¥ê³  í˜ë“¤ê¸´ ë§ˆì°¬ê°€ì§€ì˜€ë‚˜ ë³´ë‹¤.
    Geudeuldo deopgo himdeulgin machan-gajiyeonna boda.
    It looks they also felt hot and tired.
  3. a monologic interrogative suffix
    ë‚´ê°€ ë¯¸ì³¤ë‚˜, ì–´ë–»ê²Œ ì´ëŸ° ì‹¤ìˆ˜ë¥¼...
    Naega michyeonna, eotteoke ireon silsureul...
    I must have been crazy to make this ridiculous mistake..!
Usage notes

The suffix ë‚˜ (na) is directly attached to the stem of a verb, or existential adjectives ìˆë‹¤ (itda, â€œto existâ€), ì—†ë‹¤ (eopda, â€œnot to existâ€), or ê³„ì‹œë‹¤ (gyesida, â€œto exist (honorific)â€), or adjectives and ì´ë‹¤ (ida, â€œto beâ€) with past or future tense. If the stem ends with the consonant ã„¹ (l), it drops out.

Synonyms
  • â€”á†«ê°€ (n-ga) / â€”ëŠ”ê°€ (neun-ga)

Etymology 6

Korean reading of various Chinese characters.

Syllable

ë‚˜ (na)

  1. äº½, å€®, å„¸, å„º, å“ª, å–‡, å— , å›‰, å¥ˆ, å¨œ, æ‡¦, æ‡¶, æ‹, æ‹¿, æŒ, æŒª, æ›ª, æ¢›, ç˜°, ç™©, ç ¢, ç³¥, ç³¯, ç¾…, è‡, è˜¿, èº, è ƒ, è£¸, é‚, é‚£, é‘¼, é™, é›£, é¨¾, é©˜

Etymology 7

Noun

ë‚˜ â€¢ (na)

  1. si (musical note)

ë‚œ - Wiktionary

Korean

Pronunciation

  • IPA(key)[naÌ n]
  • Phonetic Hangul[ë‚œ]
Revised Romanization? nan
Revised Romanization (translit.)? nan
McCuneâ€“Reischauer? nan
Yale Romanization? nan

Etymology 1

ë‚˜ë‚™ë‚šë‚›ë‚œë‚ë‚
ë‚Ÿë‚ ë‚¡ë‚¢ë‚£ë‚¤ë‚¥
ë‚¦ë‚§ë‚¨ë‚©ë‚ªë‚«ë‚¬
ë‚­ë‚®ë‚¯ë‚°ë‚±ë‚²ë‚³
ë¼ â†â†’ ë‚´

Syllable

ë‚œ â€¢ (nan)

  1. A Hangul syllabic block made up of ã„´, ã…, and ã„´.

Etymology 2

Contraction of ë‚˜ (na, â€œIâ€) + ëŠ” (neun)

Pronoun

ë‚œ â€¢ (nan)

  1. I (topic)

Etymology 3

Korean reading of various Chinese characters

Noun

ë‚œ â€¢ (nan)

  1. äº‚: revolt
  2. æ¬„: column (of a newspaper, etc.)
  3. é›£: (In compounds) difficult, difficulty

Homophones

ä¹±, äº‚, å„, åµ, å›’, åœ, å¬¾, å¹±, æ‡¶, æ””, æš–, æ¬„, æ¬’, ç€¾, ç“, ç…–, ç…—, çˆ›, è˜­, è¥´, èµ§, é‘¾, é—Œ, é›£, é¤ª, é¸

ë‚  - Wiktionary

Korean

Pronunciation

  • IPA(key)[naÌ É­]
  • Phonetic Hangul[ë‚ ]
Revised Romanization? nal
Revised Romanization (translit.)? nal
McCuneâ€“Reischauer? nal
Yale Romanization? nal

Etymology 1

ë‚˜ë‚™ë‚šë‚›ë‚œë‚ë‚
ë‚Ÿë‚ ë‚¡ë‚¢ë‚£ë‚¤ë‚¥
ë‚¦ë‚§ë‚¨ë‚©ë‚ªë‚«ë‚¬
ë‚­ë‚®ë‚¯ë‚°ë‚±ë‚²ë‚³
ë¼ â†â†’ ë‚´

Syllable

ë‚  â€¢ (nal)

  1. A Hangul syllabic block made up of ã„´, ã…, and ã„¹.

Etymology 2

Of native Korean origin.

Noun

ë‚  â€¢ (nal)

  1. day, time
    ê·¸ëŠ” ë‚ ë§ˆë‹¤ ì¼í•˜ëŸ¬ ê°„ë‹¤.
    Geuneun nalmada ilhareo ganda.
    He goes to work every day.
    • ì–´ëŠ í•œ ë‹¹ì‚¬ìê°€ ì„œëª…í•œ ë§ˆì§€ë§‰ ë‚ 
      eoneu han dangsajaga seomyeonghan majimak nal
      the last date signed by a party
Derived terms
Derived terms
  • ê·¸ë‚  (geunal, â€œthat dayâ€)
  • ë‚˜ë‚ ì´ (nanari, â€œday after day, day by dayâ€)
  • ë‚ ë§ˆë‹¤ (nalmada, â€œeverydayâ€)
  • ë‚ ì§œ (naljja, â€œdateâ€)
  • ë‹¤ìŒë‚  (da-eumnal, â€œthe next dayâ€)
  • ë§Œë‚  (mannal, â€œalways, like everydayâ€)
  • ë§¨ë‚  (maennal, â€œeverydayâ€)
  • ì„¤ë‚  (seollal, â€œNew Year's Dayâ€)
  • ì˜›ë‚  (yennal, â€œold days, the pastâ€)
  • ì˜¤ëŠ˜ë‚  (oneullal, â€œtoday, modern timesâ€)
  • ì´ë‚  (inal, â€œthis dayâ€)
  • ì´íŠ¿ë‚  (iteunnal, â€œnext day, the following dayâ€)
  • ì „ë‚  (jeonnal, â€œthe day before, the previous dayâ€)
  • ì²«ë‚  (cheonnal, â€œfirst dayâ€)
Related terms
  • ë‚˜ì ˆ (najeol, â€œthe time during the day, half of a dayâ€)
  • ë‚® (nat, â€œdaytime, noonâ€)
  • ì˜¤ëŠ˜ (oneul, â€œtodayâ€)
See also
  • í•˜ë£¨ (haru, â€œa day, daytimeâ€)
  • ì´í‹€ (iteul, â€œtwo days, the second day of the monthâ€)
  • ì‚¬í˜ (saheul, â€œthree days, the third day of the monthâ€)
  • ë‚˜í˜ (naheul, â€œfour days, the fourth day of the monthâ€)
  • ë‹·ìƒˆ (datsae, â€œfive days, the fifth day of the monthâ€)
  • ì—¿ìƒˆ (yeotsae, â€œsix days, the sixth day of the monthâ€)
  • ì´ë ˆ (ire, â€œseven days, the seventh day of the monthâ€)
  • ì—¬ë“œë ˆ (yeodeure, â€œeight days, the eighth day of the monthâ€)
  • ì•„íë ˆ (aheure, â€œnine days, the ninth day of the monthâ€)
  • ì—´í˜ (yeolheul, â€œten days, the tenth day of the monthâ€)

Etymology 3

First attested in the Worin cheongangjigok (æœˆå°åƒæ±Ÿä¹‹æ›² / ì›”ì¸ì²œê°•ì§€ê³¡), 1449, as Middle Korean á„‚á†á†¶ (nolh). Possibly cognate with Old Japanese åˆƒ (na, â€œbladeâ€).

Noun

ë‚  â€¢ (nal)

  1. blade, edge
Synonyms
  • ë©´ë„ (myeondo, â€œrazor bladeâ€)
  • ì¹¼ (kal, â€œblade of a knife or swordâ€)
  • í†± (top, â€œsaw blade or teethâ€)
Derived terms
  • ë‚ ì¹´ë¡­ë‹¤ (nalkaropda, â€œto be sharpâ€)
Related terms
  • ë‚« (nat, â€œsickle, scytheâ€)

Etymology 4

Of native Korean origin.

Noun

ë‚  â€¢ (nal)

  1. warp, the longitudinal threads of woven cloth
Antonyms
  • ì”¨ (ssi, â€œwoof, weftâ€)

Etymology 5

Of native Korean origin. Possibly cognate with Japanese ç”Ÿ (nama, â€œrawâ€), èœ (na, â€œgreens as a food; side dishâ€) and ç”Ÿã‚‹ (naru, â€œto bear fruitâ€).

Prefix

ë‚  â€¢ (nal)

  1. raw, uncooked
Derived terms
  • ë‚ ê³„ë€ (nalgyeran, â€œraw eggâ€)
  • ë‚ ê³ ê¸° (nalgogi, â€œraw meatâ€)
  • ë‚ ë°¤ (nalbam, â€œraw, unroasted chestnutâ€)
  • ë‚ ìŒì‹ (nareumsik, â€œraw foodâ€)
Related terms
  • ë‚˜ë‹¤ (nada, â€œto be born, to appear, to come out, to growâ€)

Etymology 6

Contraction of ë‚˜ (na, â€œIâ€) + ë¥¼ (reul, object marker).

Pronoun

ë‚  â€¢ (nal)

  1. me (first person singular pronoun as object of a verb)

Etymology 7

Verb

ë‚  â€¢ (nal) (future determiner of ë‚˜ë‹¤)

  1. which will appear; which will occur

Etymology 8

Verb

ë‚  â€¢ (nal) (future determiner of ë‚ ë‹¤)

  1. who/which will fly

Etymology 9

Korean reading of various Chinese characters

Syllable

ë‚  â€¢ (nal)

  1. å‰Œ:
  2. å–‡:
  3. åŸ’:
  4. æ:
  5. æº:

  8. è¾£:

ë‚´ - Wiktionary

Korean

Etymology 1

ë‚´ë‚µë‚¶ë‚·ë‚¸ë‚¹ë‚º
ë‚»ë‚¼ë‚½ë‚¾ë‚¿ëƒ€ëƒ
ëƒ‚ëƒƒëƒ„ëƒ…ëƒ†ëƒ‡ëƒˆ
ëƒ‰ëƒŠëƒ‹ëƒŒëƒëƒëƒ
ë‚˜ â†â†’ ëƒ

Pronunciation

  • IPA(key)[neÌ]
  • Phonetic Hangul[ë‚´]
Revised Romanization? nae
Revised Romanization (translit.)? nae
McCuneâ€“Reischauer? nae
Yale Romanization? nay

Syllable

ë‚´ â€¢ (nae)

  1. A Hangul syllabic block made up of ã„´ and ã….

Etymology 2

Of native Korean origin.

Pronunciation

  • IPA(key)[neÌË]
  • Phonetic Hangul[ë‚´]
Revised Romanization? nae
Revised Romanization (translit.)? nae
McCuneâ€“Reischauer? nae
Yale Romanization? nÄy

Noun

ë‚´ â€¢ (nae)

  1. rivulet, brook, stream
    Synonym: ì‹œë‚´ (sinae)
  2. smell
    Synonym: ëƒ„ìƒˆ (naemsae)

Etymology 3

  • Contraction of ë‚˜ì´ (nai, â€œIâ€). (Note that ë‚˜ì´ is ungrammatical now.)
  • Contraction of ë‚˜ì˜ (naui, â€œmyâ€).

Pronunciation

  • IPA(key)[neÌ]
  • Phonetic Hangul[ë‚´]
Revised Romanization? nae
Revised Romanization (translit.)? nae
McCuneâ€“Reischauer? nae
Yale Romanization? nay

Pronoun

ë‚´ â€¢ (nae)

  1. I; a form of the first-person pronoun ë‚˜ (na) used before â€”ê°€ (ga)
  2. my; an abbreviated form of ë‚˜ì˜ (naui)
    • ë‚´ ê¸°ì–µì´ ë§ë‹¤ë©´ ê·¸ëŠ” êµì‚¬ì˜€ë‹¤.
      Nae gieogi matdamyeon geuneun gyosayeotda.
      If I remember right, he was a teacher.

Etymology 4

Sino-Korean word from å…§

Noun

ë‚´ â€¢ (nae) (hanja å…§)

  1. interior, inside
    ì‚¬ë¬´ì‹¤ ë‚´ì—ì„œëŠ” í¡ì—° ê¸ˆì§€ì…ë‹ˆë‹¤.
    Samusil naeeseoneun heubyeon geumjiimnida.
    Smoking is forbidden in the office.

  • ì•ˆ (an)
  • ì† (sok)
  • ë‚´ë¶€ (å…§éƒ¨, naebu)

ë„ˆ - Wiktionary

Korean

Pronunciation

  • IPA(key)[nÊŒÌ¹]
  • Phonetic Hangul[ë„ˆ]
Revised Romanization? neo
Revised Romanization (translit.)? neo
McCuneâ€“Reischauer? nÅ
Yale Romanization? ne

Etymology 1

ë„ˆë„‰ë„Šë„‹ë„Œë„ë„
ë„ë„ë„‘ë„’ë„“ë„”ë„•
ë„–ë„—ë„˜ë„™ë„šë„›ë„œ
ë„ë„ë„Ÿë„ ë„¡ë„¢ë„£
ëƒ¬ â†â†’ ë„¤

Syllable

ë„ˆ â€¢ (neo)

  1. A Hangul syllabic block made up of ã„´ and ã…“.

Etymology 2

Of native Korean origin. Possibly cognate with Old Japanese æ± (na, â€œyouâ€, second-person singular informal pronoun).

Pronoun

ë„ˆ â€¢ (neo)

  1. (informal) second-person singular informal pronoun; you
    ë„ˆë¥¼ ì‚¬ë‘í•´.
    Neoreul saranghae.
    I love you.
    ë„ˆ ì–¸ì œë¶€í„° ë‹´ë°° í”¼ìš°ê¸° ì‹œì‘í•˜ì˜€ë‹ˆ?
    Neo eonjebuteo dambae piugi sijakhayeonni?
    When did you start smoking?
    ë„ˆëŠ” ì™œ ë§í•˜ì§€ ì•Šë‹ˆ?
    Neoneun wae malhaji anni?
    Why aren't you saying anything?
Usage notes

The second person pronouns are rarely used in Korean and can be considered insulting. Instead, the person's title is often used, or ì„ ìƒë‹˜ (seonsaengnim, â€œteacherâ€) if the person's title is unknown, for strangers or superiors:

ì„ ìƒë‹˜, ì•ˆë…•í•˜ì„¸ìš”?
Seonsaengnim, annyeonghaseyo?
How are you, sir? (literally, "Teacher, are (you) at peace?")

For friends, it is more common to use the person's name.

Related terms
  • ë„ˆí¬ (neohui), ë„ˆí¬ë“¤ (neohuideul) - second-person plural informal pronoun

ëˆˆ - Wiktionary

Korean

Etymology 1

First attested in the Seokbo sangjeol (é‡‹è­œè©³ç¯€ / ì„ë³´ìƒì ˆ), 1447, as Middle Korean ëˆˆ (nwun).

Pronunciation

Revised Romanization? nun
Revised Romanization (translit.)? nun
McCuneâ€“Reischauer? nun
Yale Romanization? nwun

Noun

ëˆˆ â€¢ (nun)

  1. eye
    • ëˆˆì—ëŠ” ëˆˆ, ì´ì—ëŠ” ì´
      nuneneun nun, ieneun i
      [literally] an eye for an eye and a tooth for a tooth; tit for tat
  2. vision
    ëˆˆì´ ë°ë‹¤ â€• nuni bakda â€• to have clear vision

Of native Korean origin.

  1. bud

ë‹ˆ - Wiktionary

Korean

Etymology 1

ë‹ˆë‹‰ë‹Šë‹‹ë‹Œë‹ë‹
ë‹ë‹ë‹‘ë‹’ë‹“ë‹”ë‹•
ë‹–ë‹—ë‹˜ë‹™ë‹šë‹›ë‹œ
ë‹ë‹ë‹Ÿë‹ ë‹¡ë‹¢ë‹£
ëŠ¬ â†â†’ ë‹¤

Syllable

ë‹ˆ â€¢ (ni)

  1. A Hangul syllabic block made up of ã„´ and ã…£.

Etymology 2

First attested in the Hunmin jeongeum eonhae (è¨“æ°‘æ­£éŸ³è«ºè§£æœ¬ / í›ˆë¯¼ì •ìŒì–¸í•´ë³¸), 1447, as Middle Korean ë‹ˆ (ni).

Noun

ë‹ˆ â€¢ (ni)

  1. (archaic, now suffixal) a tooth
  2. (Pyongyang) atooth
Alternative forms
  • ì´ (i) (canonical)
Synonyms
  • ì´ë¹¨ (ippal, â€œtoothâ€) (for beasts)
Derived terms
  • ìœ—ë‹ˆ (winni, â€œthe upper teethâ€)
  • ì•„ë«ë‹ˆ (araenni, â€œthe lower teethâ€)
  • ì•ë‹ˆ (amni, â€œincisor, front toothâ€)
  • ì†¡ê³³ë‹ˆ (songgonni, â€œcuspid, canine toothâ€)
  • ì–´ê¸ˆë‹ˆ (eogeumni, â€œmolar, grinding toothâ€)
  • ì‚¬ë‘ë‹ˆ (sarangni, â€œwisdom toothâ€)
  • ë»ë“œë ë‹ˆ (ppeodeureongni, â€œbucktoothâ€)
  • ì—„ë‹ˆ (eomni, â€œ(brutal) fangâ€)
  • ì –ë‹ˆ (jeonni, â€œmilk teethâ€)
  • ê°„ë‹ˆ (ganni, â€œpermanent teethâ€)
  • í†±ë‹ˆ (tomni, â€œsaw toothâ€)
  • í†±ë‹ˆë°”í€´ (tomnibakwi, â€œtoothed wheelâ€)
See also
  • ì… (ip, â€œmouthâ€)
  • ì…ìˆ  (ipsul, â€œlipâ€)
  • ì‡ëª¸ (inmom, â€œgumâ€)
Further reading
  • tooth on Wikipedia.Wikipedia

Etymology 3

First attested in the Yongbi eocheonga (é¾é£›å¾¡å¤©æ­Œ / ìš©ë¹„ì–´ì²œê°€), 1447, as Middle Korean á„‹á†/ìœ¼ë‹ˆ (u/oni).

Suffix

â€”ë‹ˆ â€¢ (-ni)

  1. because, since
    ì›Œë‚™ ë°°ê°€ ê³ íŒ ë‹¤ ë³´ë‹ˆ ë¬´ì—‡ì„ ë¨¹ì–´ë„ ë§›ìˆì—ˆë‹¤.
    Wonak baega gopatda boni mueoseul meogeodo madisseotda.
    Everything tasted so good owing to my great hunger.
  2. and then
    ë°”ë‹·ê°€ì— ë‹¤ë‹¤ë¥´ë‹ˆ, ë§ˆì¹¨ í•˜ëŠ˜ë„. ë°”ë‹¤ë„, ë…¸ì„ì— ê°€ë“, ë¬¼ë“¤ë˜ ì°¸ì´ì—ˆë‹¤.
    Badatga-e dadareuni, machim haneuldo. Badado, no-eure gadeuk, muldeuldeon chamieotda.
    We arrived at the beach, just in time to watch, the sunset gild the sky, and the ocean, altogether.
Usage notes

The suffix ë‹ˆ (ni) takes the sequential form of a verb, an adjective, or ì´ë‹¤ (ida, â€œto beâ€), and if the stem ends in the consonant ã„¹ (l), it drops out.

Alternative forms
  • ë‹ˆê¹Œ (nikka)
Synonyms
  • ì•„/ì–´ì„œ (a/eoseo, â€œbecauseâ€)
Derived terms
  • ë”ë‹ˆ (deoni) (past retrospect)
  • ë¦¬ë‹ˆ (rini) (future, obsolete)
See also
  • ì„ í…Œë‹ˆ (eul teni)

Etymology 4

First attested in the Worin seokbo (æœˆå°é‡‹è­œ / ì›”ì¸ì„ë³´), 1459, as Middle Korean á„‹á†/ìœ¼ë‹ˆ (u/oni).

Suffix

â€”ë‹ˆ â€¢ (-ni)

  1. a plain style interrogative suffix; gives a friendlier impression than ëƒ (nya) does
    ë„ˆ ê°€ë‹ˆ?
    Neo gani?
    Do you go?
    ì—¬ìš°ì•¼, ì—¬ìš°ì•¼, ë­ í•˜ë‹ˆ?
    Yeouya, yeouya, mwo hani?
    Fox, fox, what are you doing?
Usage notes

The suffix ë‹ˆ (ni) is usually directly appended to the stem of a verb, an adjective or ì´ë‹¤ (ida, â€œto beâ€), though it rarely takes the sequential forms of the present-tense adjectives, not including ìˆë‹¤ (itda, â€œto existâ€) and ì—†ë‹¤ (eopda, â€œnot to existâ€). In all cases, if the stem ends in the consonant ã„¹ (l), it drops out.

Synonyms
  • ëƒ (nya) / ëŠëƒ (neunya)

Etymology 5

  • Contraction of ë„ˆì˜ (neoui, â€œyourâ€).

Pronoun

ë‹ˆ â€¢ (ni)

  1. your; an abbreviated form of ë„ˆì˜

Etymology 6

Korean reading of various Chinese characters.

Syllable

ë‹ˆ (ni)

  1. ä½ , å‘¢, å°¼, æ€©, æŸ…, æ³¥, ç¥¢, ç¦°, è†©, å¦®

ë‹¤ - Wiktionary

Korean

Etymology 1

ë‹¤ë‹¥ë‹¦ë‹§ë‹¨ë‹©ë‹ª
ë‹«ë‹¬ë‹­ë‹®ë‹¯ë‹°ë‹±
ë‹²ë‹³ë‹´ë‹µë‹¶ë‹·ë‹¸
ë‹¹ë‹ºë‹»ë‹¼ë‹½ë‹¾ë‹¿
ë‹ˆ â†â†’ ëŒ€

Pronunciation

  • IPA(key)[taÌ ]
  • Phonetic Hangul[ë‹¤]
Revised Romanization? da
Revised Romanization (translit.)? da
McCuneâ€“Reischauer? ta
Yale Romanization? ta

Syllable

ë‹¤ â€¢ (da)

  1. A Hangul syllabic block made up of ã„· and ã….

Etymology 2

First attested in the Yongbi eocheonga (é¾é£›å¾¡å¤©æ­Œ / ìš©ë¹„ì–´ì²œê°€), 1447, as Middle Korean ë‹¤.

Pronunciation

  • IPA(key)[taÌ Ë]
  • Phonetic Hangul[ë‹¤]
Revised Romanization? da
Revised Romanization (translit.)? da
McCuneâ€“Reischauer? ta
Yale Romanization? tÄ

Adverb

ë‹¤ â€¢ (da)

  1. all, completely
    ì²­ì†Œë¥¼ ë‹¤ í–ˆë‹¤.
    Cheongsoreul da haetda.
    I finished cleaning.
  2. nearly
    ì§‘ì— ë‹¤ ì™€ ê°„ë‹¤.
    Jibe da wa ganda.
    I'm nearly home.
  3. meaning slight surprise, exclamation, or sarcasm
    ì´ê±° ì›, ë³„ë³„ ì‚¬ëŒì„ ë‹¤ ë³´ê² ë„¤.
    Igeo won, byeolbyeol sarameul da bogenne.
    Well, I'm gonna see all kinds of people. (You are very peculiar.)
  4. (in past tense) used to say something that became unable to achieve ironically as if it were already achieved.
    ì¹œêµ¬ê°€ ë†€ìŸ€ìœ¼ë‹ˆ ì ì€ ë‹¤ ì¤ë‹¤.
    Chin-guga noljaesseuni jameun da jatda.
    'Cause my friend told me to play, I can't go to bed.

Noun

ë‹¤ â€¢ (da)

  1. (before ì´ë‹¤ (ida, â€œto be somethingâ€) and ì•„ë‹ˆë‹¤ (anida, â€œnot to be somethingâ€)) everything, all
    ê·¸ê²Œ ë‹¤(ì´)ëƒ?
    Geuge da(i)nya?
    Is that all?
    ì„±ê³µì€ ì¸ìƒì˜ ë‹¤ê°€ ì•„ë‹ˆë‹¤.
    Seonggong-eun insaeng-ui daga anida.
    Success is not everything of life.
Synonyms
  • ëª¨ë‘ (modu)
  • ì „ë¶€ (jeonbu)

Etymology 3

Pronunciation

  • IPA(key)[taÌ ]
  • Phonetic Hangul[ë‹¤]
Revised Romanization? da
Revised Romanization (translit.)? da
McCuneâ€“Reischauer? ta
Yale Romanization? ta

Noun

ë‹¤ â€¢ (da)

  1. C (musical note)

Etymology 4

Elision of ì´ in ì´ë‹¤ after a vowel.

Pronunciation

  • IPA(key)[taÌ ]
  • Phonetic Hangul[ë‹¤]
Revised Romanization? da
Revised Romanization (translit.)? da
McCuneâ€“Reischauer? ta
Yale Romanization? ta

Adjective

ë‹¤ â€¢ (da)

  1. To be (something). Used after a vowel.
Synonyms
  • ì´ë‹¤ (ida) (after a consonant)

Etymology 5

Of native Korean origin.

Suffix

â€”ë‹¤ â€¢ (-da)

  1. a plain style declarative suffix
    ë§›ìˆê² ë‹¤.
    Maditgetda.
    It looks delicious.
    ìš°ë¦¬ê°€ ì´ê²¼ë‹¤!
    Uriga igyeotda!
    It's our victory!
  2. makes the canonical form
Usage notes

The suffix ë‹¤ (da) directly follows the stem of an adjective, a verb with non-present tense, or ì´ë‹¤ (ida, â€œto beâ€), and if the stem ends in the consonant ã„¹ (l), it does not drop out. For verbs with present tense, ã„´ë‹¤ (nda, after a vowel or ã„¹ (l)) and ëŠ”ë‹¤ (neunda, after a consonant) are in use.

See also
  • ã„´ë‹¤ (nda)
  • ëŠ”ë‹¤ (neunda)

Etymology 6

Contraction of ë‹¤ê°€ (daga).

Alternative forms

  • ë‹¤ê°€ (daga)

Particle

ë‹¤ â€¢ (da)

  1. semantic marker of emphasis
    ì´ ê·¸ë¦¼ì€ ì € ë²½ì—ë‹¤ ê±¸ì–´ ì£¼ì„¸ìš”. (I geurimeun jeo byeogeda georeo juseyo., â€œPlease hang this picture on that wall.â€)
Usage notes

The particle ë‹¤ (da) is placed after some adverbs for places ending in a vowel and the particles ì— (e), ì—ê²Œ (ege), í•œí…Œ (hante) and ìœ¼ë¡œ (euro).

Suffix

â€”ë‹¤ â€¢ (-da)

  1. and then; but soon; depicts one motion or state stopping and then the other starting
    ì¢‹ë‹¤ ë§ì•˜ë„¤.
    Jota maranne.
    What a disappointment..
  2. while
    ë„ì„œê´€ì— ê³µë¶€í•˜ëŸ¬ ê°€ë‹¤ ì¹œêµ¬ë¥¼ ë§Œë‚¬ë‹¤.
    Doseogwane gongbuhareo gada chin-gureul mannatda.
    I ran into my friend when I was going to the library for my study.
  3. (in the form of '-ë‹¤ -ë‹¤') over and over
    ì—°íœ´ ë§ˆì§€ë§‰ ë‚ ì¸ ì˜¤ëŠ˜, ê²½ë¶€ ê³ ì†ë„ë¡œ ëŒ€ë¶€ë¶„ì˜ êµ¬ê°„ì—ì„œ ì°¨ëŸ‰ë“¤ì´ ê°€ë‹¤ ì„œë‹¤ë¥¼ ë°˜ë³µí•˜ê³  ìˆìŠµë‹ˆë‹¤.
    Yeonhyu majimak narin oneul, gyeongbu gosokdoro daebubunui guganeseo charyangdeuri gada seodareul banbokhago itseumnida.
    Today, the last day of the holiday, most of the Seoul-Busan highway keeps being stop-and-go.
Usage notes

The suffix ë‹¤ (da) is directly attached to the stem of a verb, an adjective, or ì´ë‹¤ (ida, â€œto beâ€), and if the stem ends in the consonant ã„¹ (l), it does not drop out.

Etymology 7

Korean reading of various Chinese characters.

Syllable

ë‹¤ (da)

  1. å¤š: many
    (eumhun reading: ë§ì„ ë‹¤ (maneul da))
  2. èŒ¶: tea
    (eumhun reading: ì°¨ ë‹¤ (cha da))
  3. çˆ¹: father
    (eumhun reading: ì•„ë¹„ ë‹¤ (abi da))

ë” - Wiktionary

Korean

Pronunciation

  • IPA(key)[tÊŒÌ¹]
  • Phonetic Hangul[ë”]
Revised Romanization? deo
Revised Romanization (translit.)? deo
McCuneâ€“Reischauer? tÅ
Yale Romanization? te

Etymology 1

ë”ë•ë–ë—ë˜ë™ëš
ë›ëœëëëŸë ë¡
ë¢ë£ë¤ë¥ë¦ë§ë¨
ë©ëªë«ë¬ë­ë®ë¯
ëŒ¸ â†â†’ ë°

Syllable

ë” â€¢ (deo)

  1. A Hangul syllabic block made up of ã„· and ã…“.

Etymology 2

Of native Korean origin.

Adverb

ë” â€¢ (deo)

  1. more; to a greater extent; -er
    ì´ ê·¸ë¦¼ì´ ìƒ‰ì´ ë” ë°ì•„ìš”.
    I geurimi saegi deo balgayo.
    This picture is brighter in color.

Etymology 3

Presumably cognate with the past continuous tense participle marker -ë˜ (deon, â€œ-deonâ€).

Suffix

â€”ë” â€¢ (--deo-)

  1. a past tense marker, suggesting that the speaker knows it from one's own experience.
    ì–´ì œ ê¸°ë¶„ ì¢‹ì•„ ë³´ì´ë”ë¼. ë¬´ìŠ¨ ì¢‹ì€ ì¼ ìˆì–´?
    Eoje gibun joa boideora. Museun joeun il isseo?
    You looked happy yesterdayâ€”did something nice happen?
Usage notes

The suffix ë” (deo) is directly appended to the stem of a verb, an adjective, or ì´ë‹¤ (ida, â€œto beâ€), or the suffix ì‹œ (-si-, honorific), ì—ˆ (-eoss-, past tense), or ê²  (-gess-, future tense). Only certain suffixes, including -ë¼ (ra), -ëƒ (nya), -ë‹ˆ (ni), -êµ¬ë‚˜ (guna), and -êµ¬ë ¤ (guryeo), follow ë” (deo).

See also
  • -ë¦¬- (ri-): a future tense marker

ë˜ - Wiktionary

Korean

Etymology

Presumably from the past continuous tense inflectional suffix -ë”- (deo-, â€œdeoâ€). Not to be confused with suffixes of similar sound -ë“  (deun, â€œdeunâ€), -ë“ ì§€ (deunji, â€œirrespective of ...â€).

Pronunciation

  • IPA(key)[tÊŒÌ¹n]
  • Phonetic Hangul[ë˜]
Revised Romanization? deon
Revised Romanization (translit.)? deon
McCuneâ€“Reischauer? tÅn
Yale Romanization? ten

Suffix

â€”ë˜ â€¢ (-deon)

  1. past continuous tense marker, making an adjective clause:
    1. after verb stems, indicates action or state which was interrupted by the occurrence of another action or state
    2. after verb stems, functions as a retrospective marker, indicates events in the past, often events which happened on a regular basis
      • ë¹„ê°€ ì˜¤ë©´ ë‚˜ê°€ ê±·ê³¤ í•˜ë˜ ëŒ€ë‚˜ë¬´ ìˆ²ê¸¸ (biga omyeon naga geotgon hadeon daenamu supgil, â€œthe lane in the bamboo grove I used to walk along when it rainedâ€)
    3. after adjective stems, indicates a state which no longer exists

ë… - Wiktionary

Korean

Etymology 1

Of native Korean origin.

Noun

ë… â€¢ (dok)

  1. pot, jar, jug (made of clay)

Etymology 2

Sino-Korean word from æ¯’

Noun

ë… â€¢ (dok) (hanja æ¯’)

  1. poison

Syllable

ë… (dok)

  1. This term needs a translation to English. Please help out and add a translation, then remove the text {{rfdef}}.

ë˜ë‹¤ - Wiktionary

Korean

Etymology

Of native Korean origin.

Pronunciation

  • IPA(key)[tweÌdaÌ ] ~ [tÃ¸ÌdaÌ ]
  • Phonetic Hangul[ë’ˆë‹¤/ë˜ë‹¤]
Revised Romanization? doeda
Revised Romanization (translit.)? doeda
McCuneâ€“Reischauer? toeda
Yale Romanization? toyta
Audio
(file)

Verb

ë˜ë‹¤ â€¢ (doeda) (infinitive ë¼ or ë˜ì–´, sequential ë˜ë‹ˆ)

  1. to become
    ì™•ì´ ë˜ë‹¤
    wang-i doeda
    to become king
  2. (of a time) to come, to arrive
    ì•½ì†í•œ ì‹œê°„ì´ ë˜ì—ˆë‹¤.
    Yaksokhan sigani doeeotda.
    The appointed time has arrived.
  3. (as an auxiliary verb after a verb in its â€”ì–´ (eo), â€”ì•„ (a), or â€”í•´ (hae) form) to be permissible; to be OK; may
    ì§ˆë¬¸ í•´ë„ ë¼ìš”?
    Jilmun haedo dwaeyo?
    May [I] ask a question?

Adjective

ë‘ - Wiktionary

Korean

Etymology 1

ë‘ë‘‘ë‘’ë‘“ë‘”ë‘•ë‘–
ë‘—ë‘˜ë‘™ë‘šë‘›ë‘œë‘
ë‘ë‘Ÿë‘ ë‘¡ë‘¢ë‘£ë‘¤
ë‘¥ë‘¦ë‘§ë‘¨ë‘©ë‘ªë‘«
ë´ â†â†’ ë‘¬

Syllable

  1. A Hangul syllabic block made up of ã„· and ã…œ.

Pronunciation

  • IPA(key)[tuË]
  • Phonetic Hangul[ë‘]
Revised Romanization? du
Revised Romanization (translit.)? du
McCuneâ€“Reischauer? tu
Yale Romanization? twÅ«

Etymology 2

First attested in the Yongbi eocheonga (é¾é£›å¾¡å¤©æ­Œ / ìš©ë¹„ì–´ì²œê°€), 1447, as Middle Korean ë‘ (twu).

Alternative forms

  • ë‘˜ (dul) (used when in isolation)

Number

ë‘ â€¢ (du)

  1. two
    • ë‘ ì—¬ìê°€ ìƒìë“¤ì„ ë‚˜ë¥´ê³  ìˆë‹¤.
      Du yeojaga sangjadeureul nareugo itda.
      Two women are carrying boxes.
    • ì˜¤ëŠ˜, ë‚œ ê·¸ ê°€ê²Œì— ë‘ ë²ˆ ë‹¤ë…€ì™”ì–´.
      Oneul, nan geu gagee du beon danyeowasseo.
      I have been to the shop twice today.

Synonyms

  • ì´ (äºŒ, i, â€œtwoâ€) (Sino-Korean)

ë‘ - Wiktionary

Korean

Etymology 1

ë¼ë½ë¾ë¿ë€ëë‚
ëƒë„ë…ë†ë‡ëˆë‰
ëŠë‹ëŒëëëë
ë‘ë’ë“ë”ë•ë–ë—
ë  â†â†’ ë˜

Syllable

ë‘ â€¢ (rang)

  1. A Hangul syllabic block made up of ã„¹, ã…, and ã…‡.

Etymology 2

Particle

ë‘ â€¢ (rang)

  1. (colloquial) and, with

Synonyms

  • í•˜ê³  (hago)

Usage notes

Used with nouns ending with a vowel, ì´ë‘ (irang) is used with nouns ending with a consonant.

Etymology 3

Korean reading of various Chinese characters.

Syllable

ë‘ (ë‘)

  1. æµª: wave
    (eumhun reading: ë¬¼ê²° ë‘ (mulgyeol rang))
  2. å»Š: aisle
    (eumhun reading: ë³µë„ ë‘ (bokdo rang))
  3. éƒ: guy
    (eumhun reading: ì‚¬ë‚´ ë‘ (sanae rang))
  4. æœ—: bright
    (eumhun reading: ë°ì„ ë‘ (balgeul rang))
  5. ç‹¼: wolf
    (eumhun reading: ì´ë¦¬ ë‘ (iri rang))
  6. ç…: gem
    (eumhun reading: ì˜¥ ì´ë¦„ ë‘ (ok ireum rang))
  7. ç‘¯: gemstone
    (eumhun reading: ì˜¥ëŒ ë‘ (okdol rang))
  8. è‚: mantis
    (eumhun reading: ì‚¬ë§ˆê·€ ë‘ (samagwi rang))

ë ¤ - Wiktionary

Korean

ë ¤ë ¥ë ¦ë §ë ¨ë ©ë ª
ë «ë ¬ë ­ë ®ë ¯ë °ë ±
ë ²ë ³ë ´ë µë ¶ë ·ë ¸
ë ¹ë ºë »ë ¼ë ½ë ¾ë ¿
ë ˆ â†â†’ ë¡€

Syllable

ë ¤ â€¢ (ryeo)

  1. A Hangul syllabic block made up of ã„¹ and ã…•.

ë¡œ - Wiktionary

Korean

Etymology 1

ë¡œë¡ë¡ë¡Ÿë¡ ë¡¡ë¡¢
ë¡£ë¡¤ë¡¥ë¡¦ë¡§ë¡¨ë¡©
ë¡ªë¡«ë¡¬ë¡­ë¡®ë¡¯ë¡°
ë¡±ë¡²ë¡³ë¡´ë¡µë¡¶ë¡·
ë¡€ â†â†’ ë¡¸

Syllable

ë¡œ â€¢ (ro)

  1. A Hangul syllabic block made up of ã„¹ and ã…—.

Etymology 2

Of native Korean origin.

Particle

ë¡œ â€¢ (ro)

  1. by means of
  2. according to
  3. by (a specified date/time)
  4. because of
  5. toward
  6. with
  7. as
Synonyms
  • ìœ¼ë¡œ (euro) (used after consonants)

Etymology 3

Sino-Korean word from è·¯ (â€œroad, path, streetâ€)

Noun

ë¡œ â€¢ (ro)

  1. avenue, road, route, street

ë¡ - Wiktionary
