ë¥¼ - Wiktionary

Korean

Alternative forms

  • (colloquial) ã„¹ (l)

Pronunciation

  • IPA(key)[É¾É¯É­]
  • Phonetic Hangul[ë¥¼]
Revised Romanization? reul
Revised Romanization (translit.)? leul
McCuneâ€“Reischauer? rÅ­l
Yale Romanization? lul

Particle

ë¥¼ â€¢ (reul)

  1. indicates the direct object of a verb

Usage notes

Like other Korean particles, ë¥¼ (reul) is a postposition. It marks the preceding noun as the direct object of the following verb. ë¥¼ (reul) is optional if it can be inferred that the noun is the direct object (as opposed to the subject).

ë¥¼ (reul) is used only after a word ending in a vowel. If the preceding word ends in a consonant, ì„ (eul) is used instead:

  • ì±… + ì„ => ì±…ì„ (chaeg + eul => chaeg-eul)
  • ì‚¬ê³¼ + ë¥¼ => ì‚¬ê³¼ë¥¼ (sagwa + reul => sagwa-reul)

If the noun is the main topic of the sentence and it can be inferred that the noun is the direct object (as opposed to the subject), ëŠ” (neun) is usually used instead.

See also

  • (subject marker) ê°€ (ga)
  • (topic marker) ëŠ” (neun)
Retrieved from "https://en.wiktionary.org/w/index.php?title=ë¥¼&oldid=49607944"
Categories:
  • Character boxes with compositions
  • Hangul Syllables block
  • Hangul script characters
  • Korean terms with IPA pronunciation
  • Korean lemmas
  • Korean particles

ë¦¬ - Wiktionary

Korean

ë¦¬ë¦­ë¦®ë¦¯ë¦°ë¦±ë¦²
ë¦³ë¦´ë¦µë¦¶ë¦·ë¦¸ë¦¹
ë¦ºë¦»ë¦¼ë¦½ë¦¾ë¦¿ë§€
ë§ë§‚ë§ƒë§„ë§…ë§†ë§‡
ë¦ â†â†’ ë§ˆ

Etymology 1

Syllable

ë¦¬ â€¢ (ri)

  1. A Hangul syllabic block made up of ã„¹ and ã…£.

Etymology 2

Suffix

â€”ë¦¬ â€¢ (-ri)

  1. a suffix deriving a passive verb.
    • ê·¸ê°€ ê°€ë°©ì„ ë“ ë‹¤. (Geuga gabang-eul deunda., â€œHe carries a bag.â€) â†’ ê°€ë°©ì´ ê·¸ì—ê²Œ ë“¤ë¦°ë‹¤. (Gabang-i geuege deullinda., â€œThe bag is carried by him.â€)

Suffix

â€”ë¦¬ â€¢ (-ri)

  1. a suffix deriving a causative verb.
    • ê·¸ê°€ ê°€ë°©ì„ ë“ ë‹¤. (Geuga gabang-eul deunda., â€œHe carries a bag.â€) â†’ ê·¸ë…€ê°€ ê·¸ì—ê²Œ ê°€ë°©ì„ ë“¤ë¦°ë‹¤. (Geunyeoga geuege gabang-eul deullinda., â€œShe has him carry the bag.â€)

Etymology 3

Suffix

â€”ë¦¬ â€¢ (--ri-)

  1. (obsolete) I guess sb will ...
    • ê·¸ëŠ” ë²Œì¨ ì €ë…ì„ ë¨¹ì—ˆìœ¼ë¦¬ë¼. (Geuneun beolsseo jeonyeogeul meogeosseurira., â€œHe might have had dinner already.â€)
  2. (obsolete) I/We will ...
    • ë‚´ ì†íˆ ë‹¤ë…€ì˜¤ë¦¬ë‹¤. (Nae sokhi danyeoorida., â€œI'll be back soon.â€)

Suffix

â€”ë¦¬ â€¢ (--ri)

  1. (obsolete) I guess sb will ...
  2. (obsolete) I/We will ...
    • ì„¸ìƒì´ ë‚˜ë¥¼ ì ˆë§ì¼€ í•´ë„ ë‚˜ëŠ” ì‚´ì•„ê°€ë¦¬. (Sesang-i nareul jeolmangke haedo naneun saragari., â€œEven with the world frustrating me, I shall live.â€)
  3. (obsolete) How on earth will I/we ...?
    • ë‚˜ë¼ë¥¼ ë¹¼ì•—ê²¼ê±°ëŠ˜, ì–´ì°Œ ê°€ë§Œíˆ ìˆì„ ìˆ˜ ìˆìœ¼ë¦¬? (Narareul ppaeatgyeotgeoneul, eojji gamanhi isseul su isseuri?, â€œThe nation being deprived of, how on earth could we stay motionless?â€)

Usage notes

The suffix -ri- is followed only by specific suffixes, including -da, -ra, -ni, -nira, therefore making combined suffixes like -rida, -rira, -rini, -rinira.

The suffix -ri takes the sequential form, and if the stem ends in ã„¹ (l), the ã„¹ (l) does not fall out.

Etymology 4

Noun

ë¦¬ â€¢ (ri) (hanja ç†)

  1. (dependent) reason, logic, (with negation) even the slightest possibility
    • ê·¸ëŸ´ ë¦¬ê°€ ì—†ë‹¤! (Geureol riga eopda!, â€œThat can't be true!â€)
    • ì£¼ì¸ê³µì´ ì£½ì„ ë¦¬ê°€ ìˆê² ëƒ? (Ju-in-gong-i jugeul riga itgennya?, â€œDo you think the main character can ever die?â€)

Noun

ë¦¬ â€¢ (ri) (hanja é‡Œ)

  1. (units of measure) li, a traditional Korean unit of distance equivalent to about 393Â m.
  2. (government) village, a Korean administrative division covering a small settlement and its surrounding hinterland.
    (Administrative divisions of South Korea) ë¦¬ (ri), ë™ (dong), ë©´ (myeon), ì (eup), êµ¬ (gu), êµ° (gun), ì‹œ (si), ë„ (do)

Proper noun

ë¦¬ â€¢ (Ri) (hanja æ)

  1. The second most common Korean surname - the North Korean spelling.
Usage notes
  • Most commonly romanized as Lee. Other romanizations include Li, Yi, Ri, and Rhee. Due to the phonology of the South Korean, the spelling ì´ (i) is used in South Korea.

Suffix

-â€”ë¦¬ â€¢ (-ri) (hanja è£¡, è£)

  1. in the center of
Derived terms
  • ì„±í™©ë¦¬ (ç››æ³è£, seonghwangni)
  • ì ˆì°¬ë¦¬ (çµ¶è®šè£¡, jeolchalli)

ë§ - Wiktionary

Korean

ë§ˆë§‰ë§Šë§‹ë§Œë§ë§
ë§ë§ë§‘ë§’ë§“ë§”ë§•
ë§–ë§—ë§˜ë§™ë§šë§›ë§œ
ë§ë§ë§Ÿë§ ë§¡ë§¢ë§£
ë¦¬ â†â†’ ë§¤

Alternative forms

  • ëª° (mol) (mostly obsolete)

Etymology 1

First recorded in the Yongbi eocheonga, 1447, as ë§.

Pronunciation

  • IPA(key)[maÌ ËÉ­]
  • Phonetic Hangul[ë§:]
Revised Romanization? mal
Revised Romanization (translit.)? mal
McCuneâ€“Reischauer? mal
Yale Romanization? mÄl

Etymology 2

Of native Korean origin.

Noun

ë§ â€¢ (mal)

  1. word, speech, language
    ë‚´ ë§ì„ ì£¼ì˜í•˜ì—¬ ë“¤ì–´ë´.
    Nae mareul juuihayeo deureobwa.
    Listen to me carefully.
Derived terms
  • ë‚±ë§ (nanmal, â€œa single wordâ€)
  • í•œêµ­ë§ (han-gungmal, â€œthe Korean languageâ€)
  • ë§ì”€ (malsseum, â€œ(honorific) wordâ€)
  • ë§í•˜ë‹¤ (malhada, â€œto say, speak, talkâ€)

See also

  • ì´ë¥´ë‹¤ (ireuda, â€œto sayâ€)

Etymology 3

First recorded in the Yongbi eocheonga, 1447, as ğ¨¥¬.

Probably related to Japanese é¦¬ (uma).

The ma sound denoting "horse" is common to a number of languages of central Asia, where horses were first domesticated, suggesting a possible cognate root. Compare Manchu á ®á £á¡µá¡³á ¨ (morin, â€œhorseâ€), Mongolian Ğ¼Ğ¾Ñ€ÑŒ (morÊ¹, â€œhorseâ€), Mandarin é¦¬ (mÇ, â€œhorseâ€), and Proto-Indo-European *mÃ¡rkos (â€œhorseâ€) and descendants such as Irish marc (â€œhorseâ€, archaic) or English mare (â€œfemale horseâ€). More at *mÃ¡rkos.

Pronunciation

  • IPA(key)[maÌ É­]
  • Phonetic Hangul[ë§]
Revised Romanization? mal
Revised Romanization (translit.)? mal
McCuneâ€“Reischauer? mal
Yale Romanization? mal

Noun

ë§ â€¢ (mal) (counter ë§ˆë¦¬)

  1. horse
  2. sawhorse
  3. checker, checkerman
Derived terms
  • ë§ì•„ì§€ (mang-aji, â€œponyâ€)
  • ì•”ë§ (ammal, â€œfemale horse, mareâ€)
  • ìˆ˜ë§ (sumal, â€œmale horseâ€)

Etymology 4

This entry lacks etymological information. If you are familiar with the origin of this term, please add it to the page per etymology instructions. You can also discuss it at the Etymology scriptorium.
Particularly: â€œHow is this "related" to a Chinese term with complete different phonetics? Also, what relation to the Japanese term å‡ (masu, â€œunit of measure for volumeâ€)? Many KO hanja readings ending in -l correspond to JA kanji readings ending variously in -shi, -chi, -tsu, and -su, opening the possibility of a KO mal <-> JA masu phonetic match. Lastly, is the prefix sense of great really from this same origin? How do the semantics work out for measure to also mean great? Perhaps this sense has a separate derivation? â†’ Notably, Japanese é¦¬ (â€œumaâ€) is also used as a prefix to mean "great, large", suggesting that the similar sense here belongs to the é¦¬ etymology above.â€

Native Korean related to Sino-Korean æ–—

Noun

ë§ â€¢ (mal)

  1. measure (containing about 18 liters or 10 doe (ë˜))
  2. a unit of measure (about 18 liters)
  3. (prefix): great, e.g., ë§ë²Œ, ë§ê°œë¯¸, ë§ì ìë¦¬
See also
  • ë˜ (doe): 1/10 mal
  • í™‰ (hop): 1/100 mal
  • ì‘ (jak): 1/1000 mal

Etymology 5

Short form of ë§ëš

Noun

ë§ â€¢ (mal)

  1. stake
    • 1461: æ©›ì€ ë§íˆë¼ (æ¥åš´ç¶“è«ºè§£ (í™œìë³¸) 8:85)

Etymology 6

First recorded in the Hunmong jahoe, 1527, as ğ¨¥¬.

Noun

ë§ â€¢ (mal)

  1. an alga or other waterborne cryptogam
  2. seaweed
    1. specifically Potamogeton oxyphyllus.
See also
  • ì¡° (è—», jo)
  • í•´ì¡° (æµ·è—», haejo)

Etymology 7

Sino-Korean word from æœ« (â€œendâ€)

Noun

ë§ â€¢ (mal) (hanja æœ«)

  1. end

    (eumhun reading: ì‹œí˜¸ ë¯¼ (siho min))

    (eumhun reading: ë‚šì‹œì¤„ ë¯¼ (naksijul min))
  19. ç½ : net
    (eumhun reading: ê·¸ë¬¼ ë¯¼ (geumul min))
  20. è‹ : vegetable heart
    (eumhun reading: ì†ëŒ€ ë¯¼ (sokdae min))
  21. é–©: tribe name
    (eumhun reading: ì¢…ì¡±ì´ë¦„ ë¯¼ (jongjogireum min))
  22. é°µ: sawedged perch
    (eumhun reading: ë‹¤ê¸ˆë°”ë¦¬ ë¯¼ (dageumbari min))
  23. é»½: exert
    (eumhun reading: í˜ì“¸ ë¯¼ (himsseul min))

Etymology 3

Inflected form

Verb

ì‚¬ - Wiktionary

Korean

Etymology 1

ì‚¬ì‚­ì‚®ì‚¯ì‚°ì‚±ì‚²

ì‚ â†â†’ ìƒˆ

Syllable

ì‚¬ â€¢ (sa)

  1. A Hangul syllabic block made up of ã…… and ã….

Etymology 2

Korean reading of various Chinese characters.

Pronunciation

  • IPA(key)[sÊ°aÌ ]
  • Phonetic Hangul[ì‚¬]
Revised Romanization? sa
Revised Romanization (translit.)? sa
McCuneâ€“Reischauer? sa
Yale Romanization? sa

Noun

ì‚¬ â€¢ (sa) (hanja ç¤¾)

  1. company

ì‚¬ â€¢ (sa) (hanja æ­»)

  1. death

Numeral

ì‚¬ â€¢ (sa) (hanja å››)

  1. (Sino-Korean numbers, cardinal) four
  2. (ordinal) fourth
Usage notes
In Modern Korean, numbers are almost always written in Arabic numerals.
ì‚¬ means â€œfourthâ€ if it is directly put before a noun other than modern units.
ì‚¬ ì¸µ: fourth floor
ë„¤ ì¸µ: four floors
ì‚¬ íŒ€: Team 4
ë„¤ íŒ€: four teams

Suffix

â€”ì‚¬ â€¢ (-sa) (hanja å²)

  1. history

Syllable

ì‚¬ â€¢ (sa)

  1. ä¹, äºŠ, äº‹, äº›, äº», ä»•, ä¼œ, ä¼º, ä¼¼, ä½€, ä½˜, ä½¿, ä¿Ÿ, å€³, å‚, å‚», åƒ¿, å„©, å†™, å†©, å‰š, å¸, å¶, å“, å², å¸, å’‹, å”†, å–³, å—„, å—£, å››, å£«, å¤•, å¥¢, å§’, å¨‘, å¯«, å¯º, å°„, å·³, å¸«, å¾™, æ€, æ¨, æ–œ, æ–¯, æŸ¥, æŸ¶, æŸ», æ¢­, æ¥‚, æ¦­, æ­», æ±œ, æ²™, æ³—, æ¸£, ç€‰, ç¼, çŠ§, çŒ®, ç…, ç», ç—§, çš¶, ç ‚, ç¤¾, ç¥€, ç¥ , ç§, ç«¢, ç¬¥, ç¯©, ç°‘, ç°”, ç³¸, ç´—, çµ², ç¼·, è‚†, èˆ, è, è“‘, è›‡, èœ¡, è£Ÿ, è¦—, è©, è©, è¬, è³œ, èµ¦, è¾, è¾­, é‚ª, é£Ÿ, é£¼, é§›, é§Ÿ, é­¦, é¯Š, é¯‹, é°¤, éº

ì‚¬ â€¢ (sa)

  1. sol (musical note)

  1. A Hangul syllabic block made up of ã…… and ã…—.

Etymology 2

First attested in the Hunmin jeongeum haerye (è¨“æ°‘æ­£éŸ³è§£ä¾‹ / í›ˆë¯¼ì •ìŒí•´ë¡€), 1446, as Middle Korean ì‡¼ (syo).

ìˆ˜ - Wiktionary

Korean

Pronunciation

  • IPA(key)[sÊ°u]
  • Phonetic Hangul[ìˆ˜]
Revised Romanization? su
Revised Romanization (translit.)? su
McCuneâ€“Reischauer? su
Yale Romanization? swu

Etymology 1

ìˆ˜ìˆ™ìˆšìˆ›ìˆœìˆìˆ
ìˆŸìˆ ìˆ¡ìˆ¢ìˆ£ìˆ¤ìˆ¥
ìˆ¦ìˆ§ìˆ¨ìˆ©ìˆªìˆ«ìˆ¬
ìˆ­ìˆ®ìˆ¯ìˆ°ìˆ±ìˆ²ìˆ³
ì‡¼ â†â†’ ìˆ´

Syllable

ìˆ˜ â€¢ (su)

  1. A Hangul syllabic block made up of ã…… and ã…œ.

Etymology 2

Of native Korean origin.

Noun

ìˆ˜ â€¢ (su)

  1. way, means, possibility
  2. male (non-human)

Usage notes

After a future determiner and before, ìˆ˜ (su, â€œpossibilityâ€) with a form of ìˆë‹¤ (itda, â€œto existâ€) or ì—†ë‹¤ (eopda, â€œnot to existâ€) may translate as a form of â€œcanâ€ or â€œcannotâ€, respectively:

  • ë§ˆê°ê¸°í•œì„ ë§ì¶œ ìˆ˜ ìˆì–´ìš”.
    Magamgihaneul matchul su isseoyo.
    I can meet the deadline.
  • ê°ˆ ìˆ˜ê°€ ì—†ìŠµë‹ˆë‹¤.
    Gal suga eopseumnida.
    [I] cannot go. (Literally, "The future going possibility does not exist.")

Antonyms

  • (male): ì•” (am, â€œfemale (non-human)â€)

Etymology 3

Korean reading of various Chinese characters.

Noun

ìˆ˜ â€¢ (su) (hanja æ•¸)

  1. number
    • ìˆ˜ë¥¼ ì„¸ë‹¤ â€• sureul seda â€• to count (the number of)

ìˆ˜ â€¢ (su) (hanja æ°´)

  1. water
  2. river
  3. (figuratively) north; winter; black

Abbreviation

ìˆ˜ â€¢ (su) (hanja æ°´)

  1. Abbreviation of ìˆ˜ìš”ì¼ (suyoil): Wednesday

ì‹œ - Wiktionary

Korean

Pronunciation

  • IPA(key)[É•Ê°i]
  • Phonetic Hangul[ì‹œ]
Revised Romanization? si
Revised Romanization (translit.)? si
McCuneâ€“Reischauer? si
Yale Romanization? si

Etymology 1

ì‹œì‹ì‹ì‹Ÿì‹ ì‹¡ì‹¢
ì‹£ì‹¤ì‹¥ì‹¦ì‹§ì‹¨ì‹©
ì‹ªì‹«ì‹¬ì‹­ì‹®ì‹¯ì‹°
ì‹±ì‹²ì‹³ì‹´ì‹µì‹¶ì‹·
ì‹€ â†â†’ ì‹¸

Syllable

ì‹œ â€¢ (si)

  1. A Hangul syllabic block made up of ã…… and ã…£.

Etymology 2

Suffix

â€”ì‹œ â€¢ (-si)

  1. honorably, rightly, justly; the honorific suffix applied to verbs and adjectives

Usage notes

The honorific form of verbs expresses the social superiority of the subject of the sentence to the speaker. As applied to adjectives, it expresses the relationship between the modified noun and the speaker.

The honorific form is constructed by appending ì‹œ (si) to the sequential form of a verb or an adjective.

Plain (non-honorific) Sequential Honorific
í•˜ë‹¤ (hada, "to do") í•˜ë‹ˆ (hani) í•˜ì‹œë‹¤ (hasida, "to do (by someone superior to the speaker)"
ê°€ë‹¤ (gada, "to go") ê°€ë‹ˆ (gani) ê°€ì‹œë‹¤ (gasida, "to go (by someone superior to the speaker)"
ì‚´ë‹¤ (salda, "to live") ì‚¬ë‹ˆ (sani) ì‚¬ì‹œë‹¤ (sasida, "to live (by someone superior to the speaker)"
ì‘ë‹¤ (jakda, "(to be) small") ì‘ìœ¼ë‹ˆ (jageuni) ì‘ìœ¼ì‹œë‹¤ (jageusida, "(for something superior to the speaker) to be small"
ê³±ë‹¤ (gopda, "(to be) lovely") ê³ ìš°ë‹ˆ (gouni) ê³ ìš°ì‹œë‹¤ (gousida, "(for someone superior to the speaker) to be lovely"

See also

  • ë‹˜ (nim), the honorific suffix for many nouns

Etymology 3

Korean reading of various Chinese characters.

Noun

ì‹œ â€¢ (si, McCune-Reischauer: shi) (hanja å¸‚)

  1. town, city
    • ì‹œì˜íšŒëŠ” ê·¸ ë¬¸ì œê°€ ì£¼ë¯¼ íˆ¬í‘œë¥¼ ê±°ì³ì•¼ í•  ì‚¬ì•ˆì´ë¼ê³  ê²°ì •í•˜ì˜€ë‹¤.
      Siuihoeneun geu munjega jumin tupyoreul geochyeoya hal saanirago gyeoljeonghayeotda.
      The city council decided the matter should go to public vote.
  2. (South Korea, government) an administrative region, a division of a province having a population of over 150,000
    (Administrative divisions of South Korea) ë¦¬ (ri), ë™ (dong), ë©´ (myeon), ì (eup), êµ¬ (gu), êµ° (gun), ì‹œ (si), ë„ (do)

Noun

ì‹œ â€¢ (si, McCune-Reischauer: shi) (hanja è©©)

  1. poem, poetry

Noun

ì‹œ â€¢ (si, McCune-Reischauer: shi) (hanja æ™‚)

  1. time
  2. hour

Noun

ì‹œ â€¢ (si) (hanja æ–½)

  1. give, grant, bestow

Noun

ì‹œ â€¢ (si) (hanja åª¤)

  1. husband's family

ì‹  - Wiktionary

Korean

Etymology 1

ì‹œì‹ì‹ì‹Ÿì‹ ì‹¡ì‹¢

  • Phonetic Hangul[ì‹ ]

Syllable

ì‹  â€¢ (sin)

  1. A Hangul syllabic block made up of ã……, ã…£, and ã„´.

Etymology 2

Sino-Korean word from ç¥ (â€œgodâ€)

Noun

ì‹  â€¢ (sin, McCune-Reischauer: shin, Yale: sin) (hanja ç¥)

  1. god, God
  2. spirit, departed soul
    ë•…ì´ æ··æ²Œí•˜ê³  ç©ºè™›í•˜ë©° é»‘æš—ì´ ê¹ŠìŒ ìœ„ì— ìˆê³  í•˜ë‚˜ë‹˜ì˜ ç¥ì€ æ°´é¢ì— é‹è¡Œí•˜ì‹œë‹ˆë¼
    ë•…ì´ í˜¼ëˆí•˜ê³  ê³µí—ˆí•˜ë©°; í‘ì•”ì´ ê¹ŠìŒ ìœ„ì— ìˆê³ . í•˜ë‚˜ë‹˜ì˜ ì‹ ì€ ìˆ˜ë©´ì— ìš´í–‰í•˜ì‹œë‹ˆë¼.     (Korean Bible, ì°½ì„¸ê¸° (Genesis) 1:2)
    Ttang-i hondonhago gongheohamyeo; heugami gipeum wie itgo. Hananimui sineun sumyeone unhaenghasinira.
    And the earth was without form, and void; and darkness was upon the face of the deep. And the Spirit of God moved upon the face of the waters.

Etymology 3

Of native Korean origin.

Noun

ì‹  â€¢ (sin, McCune-Reischauer: shin, Yale: sin)

  1. joy, delight, amusement
    ê´€ì¤‘ë“¤ì€ ì•„ì£¼ ì‹ ì´ ë‚¬ì—ˆë‹¤.
    Gwanjungdeureun aju sini nasseotda.
    The audience was frantic with joy.

Etymology 4

Of native Korean origin.

ì•  â†â†’ ì–˜

ì–‘ â€¢ (yang)

Etymology 2

Sino-Korean word from è‰¯ (â€œgood, virtuous, respectableâ€)

Alternative forms

  • (North Korea) ëŸ‰ (ryang)

Noun

  1. (performance level) good, fine

ì— - Wiktionary

Korean

Pronunciation

  • IPA(key)[eÌ]
  • Phonetic Hangul[ì—]
Revised Romanization? e
Revised Romanization (translit.)? e
McCuneâ€“Reischauer? e
Yale Romanization? ey

Etymology 1

ì—ì—‘ì—’ì—“ì—”ì—•ì—–
ì——ì—˜ì—™ì—šì—›ì—œì—
ì—ì—Ÿì— ì—¡ì—¢ì—£ì—¤
ì—¥ì—¦ì—§ì—¨ì—©ì—ªì—«
ì–´ â†â†’ ì—¬

Syllable

ì— â€¢ (e)

  1. A Hangul syllabic block made up of ã…‡ and ã…”.

Etymology 2

This entry lacks etymological information. If you are familiar with the origin of this term, please add it to the page per etymology instructions. You can also discuss it at the Etymology scriptorium.
Particularly: â€œAre there any earlier forms of this attested in MK? And does the spelling suggest an earlier form that might have been a diphthong?â€

Particle

ì— â€¢ (e)

  1. at
  2. to
    ì–´ë””ì— ê°€ìš”?
    Eodie gayo?
    Where are you going to?
Usage notes

ì— (e) is only used on nouns denoting inanimate objects. For nouns denoting animate objects (usually people or animals), í•œí…Œ (hante), ì—ê²Œ (ege), or ê²Œ (ge) is used instead.

See also
  • ìœ¼ë¡œ (euro) / ë¡œ (ro)

ìš° - Wiktionary

Korean

Etymology 1

ìš°ìš±ìš²ìš³ìš´ìšµìš¶
ìš·ìš¸ìš¹ìšºìš»ìš¼ìš½
ìš¾ìš¿ì›€ì›ì›‚ì›ƒì›„
ì›…ì›†ì›‡ì›ˆì›‰ì›Šì›‹
ìš” â†â†’ ì›Œ

Syllable

ìš° â€¢ (u)

  1. A Hangul syllabic block made up of ã…‡ and ã…œ.

Etymology 2

Of native Korean origin.

Adverb

ìš° â€¢ (u)

  1. suddenly

Noun

ìš° â€¢ (u)

  1. the name of the hangeul vowel ã…œ (u)
  2. (North Korea) above; top
    • 2004 October 10, "êµ¬ë¦„ìš°ì— ì†Ÿì€ ã€Šì™•ã€‹ë“¤ì˜ ì§‘-13ê°œì˜ ë¶„êµ" (The House of "Kings", Soaring Above the Clouds), KCNA[1]:
      ì´ê³³ì—ì„œ ë‚´ë ¤ë‹¤ë³´ë©´ ë§ˆì¹˜ êµ¬ë¦„ìš°ì— ë¶„êµì™€ ë§ˆì„ì´ ë‘¥ë‘¥ ë– ìˆëŠ”ê²ƒë§Œ ê°™ë‹¤.
      igos-eseo naeryeodabomyeon machi gureum-u-e bun-gyo-wa ma-eur-i dungdung tteo-inneun-geon-man gatda.
      Looking down from here, it looks just like the schoolhouse and the village are floating separately above the clouds.
Alternative forms
  • (above): ìœ„ (wi) (South Korea)

Etymology 3

Of native Korean origin.

Suffix

â€”ìš° â€¢ (-u)

  1. a suffix deriving a causative verb.
    • ìë¦¬ê°€ ë¹„ì—ˆë‹¤. (Jariga bieotda., â€œThe seat became empty.â€) â†’ ì‚¬ì¥ì´ ìë¦¬ë¥¼ ë¹„ì› ë‹¤. (Sajang-i jarireul biwotda., â€œThe boss is absent. (The boss made his seat empty.)â€)
Synonyms
  • -ì´ (i)/íˆ (hi)/ë¦¬ (ri)/ê¸° (gi)/êµ¬ (gu)/ì¶” (chu)-Â : suffixes deriving causative verbs.

Etymology 4

Of native Korean origin.

Alternative forms

  • ìˆ˜ (su)

Suffix

â€”ìš° â€¢ (-u)

  1. one of the middle style (í•˜ì˜¤ì²´) declarative, interrogative, and imperative endings, often used by senior women to higher but familiar women.
    • ì–¸ë‹ˆëŠ” ë¹¨ê°„ ë‚ ì— ì–´ë”” ê°€ì‹œìš°? (Eonnineun ppalgan nare eodi gasiu?, â€œWhere are you going on the holiday?â€)

Usage notes

This is used after a vowel, or the consonant ã„¹ (l) in which case the ã„¹ (l) falls out. After a consonant other than ã„¹ (l), ìˆ˜ (su) is used instead.

Synonyms

  • ì˜¤ (o) / ì†Œ (so)

Etymology 5

Korean reading of various Chinese characters.

Noun

ìš° â€¢ (u) (hanja å³)

  1. the right side

ìš° â€¢ (u) (hanja æ„š)

  1. foolishness

ìš° â€¢ (u) (hanja å„ª)

  1. superiority; excellence

ìš° â€¢ (u) (hanja ç¾½)

  1. the fifth note in the pentatonic scale; la

ìš¸ - Wiktionary

Korean

ìš°ìš±ìš²ìš³ìš´ìšµìš¶
ìš·ìš¸ìš¹ìšºìš»ìš¼ìš½

ìš” â†â†’ ì›Œ

Pronunciation

  • IPA(key)[uÉ­]
  • Phonetic Hangul[ìš¸]
Revised Romanization? ul
Revised Romanization (translit.)? ul
McCuneâ€“Reischauer? ul
Yale Romanization? wul

Etymology 1

Of native Korean origin.

Noun

ìš¸ â€¢ (ul)

  1. wall, fence
  2. cage
Synonyms
  • ë‹´ (dam): wall
  • ë°”ëŒ (baram): wall
  • ë°”ëŒë²½ (ë°”ëŒå£, barambyeok): wall
  • ë²½ (å£, byeok): wall

  • ìš¸íƒ€ë¦¬ (ultari): fence

Etymology 2

Pronoun

ìš¸ â€¢ (ul)

  1. we, our

Etymology 3

Noun

  1. family, friend, kinsfolk, relatives

Etymology 4

ìš¸ â€¢ (ul)

  1. wool

ì›Œ - Wiktionary

ì€ - Wiktionary

Korean

Etymology 1

ìœ¼ìœ½ìœ¾ìœ¿ì€ìì‚
ìƒì„ì…ì†ì‡ìˆì‰
ìŠì‹ìŒìììì
ì‘ì’ì“ì”ì•ì–ì—
ìœ  â†â†’ ì˜

Syllable

ì€ â€¢ (eun)

  1. A Hangul syllabic block made up of ã…‡, ã…¡, and ã„´.

Pronunciation

  • IPA(key)[É¯n]
  • Phonetic Hangul[ì€]
Revised Romanization? eun
Revised Romanization (translit.)? eun
McCuneâ€“Reischauer? Å­n
Yale Romanization? un

Etymology 2

Of native Korean origin.

Particle

ì€ â€¢ (eun)

  1. ì€ (eun) marks the topic of the sentence. The topic of a sentence is not to be confused with the subject of the sentence.
  2. ì€ (eun), depending on context, shows contrast with or adds emphasis to the preceding word or phrase in a sentence.

Usage notes

ì€ (eun) is always used after a word (a noun, a noun phrase, or a nominalized verb/adjective in ã… form), ending in a consonant. Identical in meaning to ëŠ” (neun) which occurs only after a word ending in a vowel.

  • (topic marker): The topic is what is being talked about in the sentence, it is the main point. This however is different in meaning from the subject which the predicate directly refers to. The topic and subject may be the same in a sentence. For example,
    • ë§¤ë¦¬ëŠ” ë‚´ ì¹œêµ¬ë‹¤. (Mary-neun nae chingu-da.) â€” â€œMary is my friend.â€
    In this case "Mary" is the topic (and the subject) of this sentence and "is my friend" is the predicate. However, in many cases, the subject and topic are different.
    • ì´ ë°˜ì€ í•™ìƒì´ ë˜‘ë˜‘í•˜ë‹¤. (I ban-eun haksaeng-i ddokddokhada.) â€” â€œSpeaking of this class, the students are smart.â€
    Above, the topic is "This class" while the subject is "the students".
    In cases like this, the topic can often be thought of as a range, or to what extent the sentence is applicable. In the example above, if "speaking of this class" was removed, the sentence would not be limited to "this class", and would talk about all students in general.
  • (Contrast/emphasis marker): ì€ (eun), can be placed after most case markers (including ê°€ (ga), ë¥¼ (reul), ì— (e), ì—ê²Œ (ege), ì—ì„œ (eseo), ë¡œ (ro), ê³¼ (gwa)) to show contrast between two or more choices or add emphasis to a word or phrase, depending on the context. If used after ê°€ (ga) or ë¥¼ (reul), the ê°€ (ga) or ë¥¼ (reul) are deleted leaving only ì€ (eun).
    • ë‚˜ëŠ” ì„œìš¸ì— ê°€ê³  ì‹¶ë‹¤. (Na-neun Seoul-e ganda.) â€” â€œI want to go to Seoul.â€
    • ë‚˜ëŠ” ì„œìš¸ì—ëŠ” ê°€ê³  ì‹¶ë‹¤. (Na-neun Seoul-e-neun ganda.) â€” â€œI want to go to Seoul (and not Busan).â€ or â€œI want to (especially) go to Seoul.â€
    • ë‚˜ëŠ” ì¡´ì—ê²Œ ì±…ì„ ì£¼ì—ˆë‹¤. (Na-neun John-ege chaeg-eul jueotta.) â€” â€œI gave John a book.â€
    • ë‚˜ëŠ” ì¡´ì—ê²ŒëŠ” ì±…ì„ ì£¼ì—ˆë‹¤. (Na-neun John-ege-neun chaeg-eul juotta.) â€” â€œI gave John (and not Fred) a book.â€ or â€œI gave (especially) John a book.â€
    In cases where there are two cases of either ëŠ” (neun) or ì€ (eun) in a sentence it is assumed that the first usage refers to the topic while the second usage refers to some contrast or emphasis.

Synonyms

  • (used after a word ending in a vowel) ëŠ” (neun)

See also

  • ì´ (i), ê°€ (ga)

Etymology 3

Korean reading of various Chinese characters.

Noun

ì€ â€¢ (eun) (hanja éŠ€)

  1. silver

Derived terms

  • ë°±ì€ (ç™½éŠ€, baegeun)
Retrieved from "https://en.wiktionary.org/w/index.php?title=ì€&oldid=49268915"

ì„ - Wiktionary

Korean

ìœ¼ìœ½ìœ¾ìœ¿ì€ìì‚
ìƒì„ì…ì†ì‡ìˆì‰
ìŠì‹ìŒìììì
ì‘ì’ì“ì”ì•ì–ì—
ìœ  â†â†’ ì˜

Etymology 1

Particle

ì„ â€¢ (-eul)

  1. particle indicating the direct object of a verb
Usage notes
  • Like other Korean particles, ì„ (eul) is a postposition. It marks the preceding noun as the direct object of the following verb.
  • ì„ (-eul) only comes after a word ending in a consonant. If the modified word ends in a vowel, ë¥¼ (-reul) is used instead:
  • ì±… + ì„ => ì±…ì„
    chaek + eul => chaeg-eul
  • ì‚¬ê³¼ + ë¥¼ => ì‚¬ê³¼ë¥¼
    sagwa + reul => sagwa-reul
  • ì„ (-eul) is optional if it can be inferred that the noun is the direct object (as opposed to the subject).

If the noun is the main topic of the sentence and it can be inferred that the noun is the direct object (as opposed to the subject), ì€ (-eun) may be used instead, though in many cases ì€ (-eun) might be interpreted as a contrast.

See also
  • ì´ (i)
  • ì€ (eun)

Etymology 2

Suffix

â€”ì„ â€¢ (--eul)

  • alternative form of ã„¹ (-l), used after consonants
  1. An ending of a word that makes the preceding statement function as an adnominal phrase.
    ì´ ë²„ì„¯ë“¤ì€ ë¨¹ì„ ìˆ˜ ìˆë‹¤.
    I beoseotdeureun meogeul su itda.
    These mushrooms are edible.
  2. that will; who will (An ending of a word that makes the preceding statement function as an adnominal phrase and indicates assumption, prearrangement, intention, possibility, etc.)
Retrieved from "https://en.wiktionary.org/w/index.php?title=ì„&oldid=49994984"

ì¥ - Wiktionary

Korean

Etymology

ìì‘ì’ì“ì”ì•ì–
ì—ì˜ì™ìšì›ìœì
ììŸì ì¡ì¢ì£ì¤
ì¥ì¦ì§ì¨ì©ìªì«
ì´ â†â†’ ì¬
ìì‘ì’ì“ì”ì•ì–
ì—ì˜ì™ìšì›ìœì
ììŸì ì¡ì¢ì£ì¤
ì¥ì¦ì§ì¨ì©ìªì«
ì´ â†â†’ ì¬

Syllable

ì¥ â€¢ (jang)

  1. A Hangul syllabic block made up of ã…ˆ, ã…, and ã…‡.

Noun

ì¥ (jang)

  1. å ´: site, market, marketplace, scene (of a play)
  2. ç« : emblem, chapter (of a book, etc.)
  3. å¼µ: sheet (of paper)
  4. é•·: head (of an organization), chief (mostly in compound words)
  5. è…¸: intestines
  6. æ¬Œ: cabinet (furniture)
  7. å°‡: general (mostly in compound words)
  8. é†¬: sauce, marmalade, jam, compote (stewed fruit), preserved vegetables, preserved fruit

Derived terms

  • ê°„ì¥ (ganjang)
  • ê°œì¥ (ê°œé†¬, gaejang)
  • ê°œì¥êµ­ (ê°œé†¬êµ­, gaejangguk)
  • ê³ ì¶”ì¥ (gochujang)
  • ëœì¥ (ëœé†¬, doenjang)
  • ìƒì¶”ìŒˆ (sangchussam)
  • ìŒˆì¥ (ssamjang)
  • ì¥ë…ëŒ€ (jangdokdae)
  • ì¥ì•„ì°Œ (jang-ajji)
  • ì¥í™” (janghwa)
  • ì²­êµ­ì¥ (æ·¸éº´é†¬, cheonggukjang)
  • ì´ˆê³ ì¶”ì¥ (chogochujang)

Proper noun

ì¥ (chang, jang, cang)

  1. å¼µ: a Korean surname
  2. ç« : a Korean surname
  3. èŠ: a Korean surname

ì¤‘ - Wiktionary

Korean

Etymology 1

ì£¼ì£½ì£¾ì£¿ì¤€ì¤ì¤‚
ì¤ƒì¤„ì¤…ì¤†ì¤‡ì¤ˆì¤‰
ì¤Šì¤‹ì¤Œì¤ì¤ì¤ì¤

ì£  â†â†’ ì¤˜

Pronunciation

  • IPA(key)[tÍ¡É•uÅ‹]
  • Phonetic Hangul[ì¤‘]
Revised Romanization? jung
Revised Romanization (translit.)? jung
McCuneâ€“Reischauer? chung
Yale Romanization? cwung

Syllable

  1. A Hangul syllabic block made up of ã…ˆ, ã…œ, and ã…‡.

Etymology 2

Sino-Korean word from ä¸­ (â€œcenterâ€)

Noun

ì¤‘ â€¢ (jung)

  1. the middle, center
  2. (dependent noun) amongst (often in the form ì¤‘ì—ì„œ (jung-eseo, â€œfrom amongstâ€))
  3. (dependent noun) in the course of, during
    ì‹ì‚¬ì¤‘ (siksajung, â€œgone to lunchâ€)
    ê³µì‚¬ì¤‘ (gongsajung, â€œunder constructionâ€)

  • ì† (sok, â€œinsideâ€)

    (eumhun reading: ë²„ê¸ˆ ì¤‘ (beogeum jung))

ì§€ - Wiktionary

Korean

Etymology 1

ì§€ì§ì§‚ì§ƒì§„ì§…ì§†
ì§‡ì§ˆì§‰ì§Šì§‹ì§Œì§
ì§ì§ì§ì§‘ì§’ì§“ì§”
ì§•ì§–ì§—ì§˜ì§™ì§šì§›
ì¦¤ â†â†’ ì§œ

Syllable

ì§€ â€¢ (ji)

  1. A Hangul syllabic block made up of ã…ˆ and ã…£.

Etymology 2

First attested in the Seokbo sangjeol (é‡‹è­œè©³ç¯€ / ì„ë³´ìƒì ˆ), 1447, as Middle Korean ë””.

Noun

ì§€ â€¢ (ji)

  1. since (somebody) last (did something); from the time that
Usage notes

In the sense of "since", ì§€ indicates a period of time. The verb or adjective immediately preceding ì§€ must be in the attributive form (-ã„´). This attributive form may follow the adverbs ëª» or ì•ˆ. Although ì§€ means â€˜sinceâ€™ as used with durations, usage differs from English â€˜sinceâ€™ insofar as the Korean verb preceding ì§€ should be negated where the English clause containing â€˜sinceâ€™ would not, and vice versa: Compare negative Korean â€œâ€¦ ì•ˆ í•œ ì§€â€ with positive English â€œsince (somebody) last â€¦edâ€.

The ì§€ sentence must end in the combination of a timespan (for example 2ì£¼) or a question verb asking â€œhow longâ€ (for example ëª‡ ì£¼) and a verb such as ë˜ë‹¤ or ì§€ë‚˜ë‹¤.

Examples:

  • ì–´ë¨¸ë‹ˆë¥¼ ëµŒ ì§€ ë²Œì¨ ì˜¤ë˜ë˜ì—ˆë‹¤.
    â€œIt has already been a long time since I've seen my mother.â€
  • ë¨¸ë¦¬ë¥¼ ëª»/ì•ˆ ê°ì€ ì§€ 2ì£¼ì¯¤ ë˜ë©´ ëŠë‚Œì´ ì–´ë–¨ê¹Œìš”?
    â€œWhat will it feel like when (somebody hasn't) washed (their) hair for two weeks?â€

Compare ë§Œ and ë¶€í„° which differ from ì§€ in usage.

Etymology 3

Of native Korean origin.

Suffix

â€”ì§€ â€¢ (-ji)

  1. verb suffix used to seek affirmation, or to give the listener(s) an opportunity to express whether they can follow or not, to agree, or to confirm what is said:
    â€œì–´ë µì§€?â€
    â€œeoryeopji?â€
    It's difficult, isn't it?
    â€œí•œêµ­ë§ì„ ì´í•´í•˜ì‹œì§€?â€
    â€œhan-gungmareul ihaehasiji?â€
    You understand Korean, right?
  2. verb suffix a speaker uses to recommend a change in the listener's behaviour, or to soften imperatives:
    (To a hasty eater)
    â€œì²œì²œíˆ ë¨¹ì§€â€
    â€œcheoncheonhi meokjiâ€
    Eat slowly.
Derived terms
  • ì£  (jyo)

Etymology 4

Of native Korean origin.

Suffix

â€”ì§€ â€¢ (-ji)

  1. suffix either marking the verb that is negated by following ëª»í•˜ë‹¤/ì•Šë‹¤, or marking what a following ë§ë‹¤ says not to do:
    â€œë‹´ë°°ë¥¼ í”¼ìš°ì§€ ë§™ì‹œë‹¤.â€
    â€œdambaereul piuji mapsida.â€
    Let's not smoke cigarettes.
    • ì§€ can optionally receive markers such as ëŠ”, ê°€, and ë¥¼:
      ë§ì§€ê°€ ì•Šì•„ìš”
      manchiga anayo
      â€¦Â is not much
    • ì§€ is not used to form a negative copula:
      â€œë‹¤ê°€ ì•„ë‹ˆë‹¤â€
      â€œdaga anidaâ€
      â€¦Â is not all
    • ì§€ is used when saying some action was a mistake (for example when regretting something), and when thinking about better not doing something:
      â€œâ€¦Â ì„œìš¸ì— ì˜¤ì§€ ë§ ê±¸ ê·¸ë¬ë„¤ìš”.â€
      â€œâ€¦Â Seoure oji mal geol geuraenneyo.â€
      â€œâ€¦Â shouldn't have come to Seoul.â€
      â€œâ€¦Â ì„œìš¸ì— ê°€ì§€ ë§ê¹Œ ìƒê°ë„ í•´ ë´¤ì§€ë§ŒÂ â€¦.â€
      â€œâ€¦Â Seoure gaji malkka saenggakdo hae bwatjimanÂ â€¦.â€
      â€œâ€¦Â have/has been thinking about not going to Seoul, butÂ â€¦â€
      But:
      â€œì„œìš¸ì— ì•ˆ ê°€ëŠ” ê²Œ ë‚˜ì„ ê²ƒ ê°™ì§€ìš”.â€
      â€œSeoure an ganeun ge na-eul geot gatjiyo.â€
      Not going to Seoul seems better; don't you think so?

See also

  • -ã„´ì§€ (-nji) / -ëŠ”ì§€ (neunji) / -ã„¹ì§€ (-lji) / -ë˜ì§€ (-deonji)

Etymology 5

Colloquial variant of ì € (jeo, â€œoneselfâ€)

Pronoun

ì§€ â€¢ (ji)

  1. (colloquial) oneself; the aforementioned one
    ì§€ëŠ” í•  ê±° ë‹¤ í•˜ê³  ì‚´ë©´ì„œ ë§¨ë‚  ë‚˜ë³´ê³  ë­ë¼ ê·¸ë˜.
    Jineun hal geo da hago salmyeonseo maennal nabogo mwora geurae.
    He does all what he wants and he tells me off everyday!

Synonyms

  • ìê¸° (jagi)

Etymology 6

Korean reading of various Chinese characters.

Noun

ì§€ â€¢ (ji, McCune-Reischauer: chi, Yale: ci) (hanja ç¯ª)

  1. an ancient bamboo flute with five finger holes; used in aak

ì§„ - Wiktionary

Korean

Etymology 1

Syllable

  1. A Hangul syllabic block made up of ã…ˆ, ã…£, and ã„´.

Etymology 2

Korean reading of various Chinese characters.

Syllable

ì§„ (jin)

  1. é€²: progression

    (eumhun reading: ë‹¤í•  ì§„ (dahal jin))

    (eumhun reading: ë‘ë ê¸¸ ì§„ (dureonggil jin))
  32. ç¸: hemp yarn
    (eumhun reading: ì‚¼ì‹¤ ì§„ (samsil jin))
  33. è‡»: arriving
    (eumhun reading: ì´ë¥¼ ì§„ (ireul jin))
  34. è”¯: a kind of chrysanthemum
    (eumhun reading: ë”ìœ„ì§€ê¸° ì§„ (deowijigi jin))
  35. è¢—: unhemmed garments
    (eumhun reading: í™‘ì˜· ì§„ (hotot jin))

Etymology 3

Hangulization of various English words.

Noun

ì§„ â€¢ (jin)

  1. jeans, or jean fabric
  2. gin

Etymology 4

Determinative form of various Korean verbs and adjectives.

Adjective

ì§„ â€¢ (jin) (determiner of ì§ˆë‹¤)

  1. wet, watery

Verb

ì§„ â€¢ (jin) (past-tense determiner of ì§€ë‹¤)

  1. having lost.

ì¹˜ - Wiktionary

Korean

Pronunciation

  • IPA(key)[tÍ¡É•Ê°i]
  • Phonetic Hangul[ì¹˜]
Revised Romanization? chi

ì¸¼ â†â†’ ì¹´

Syllable

ì¹˜ â€¢ (chi)

  1. A Hangul syllabic block made up of ã…Š and ã…£.

Etymology 2

Korean reading of various Chinese characters.

Noun 1

ì¹˜ â€¢ (chi) (hanja é½’)

  1. tooth or teeth
Synonyms
  • ì´ (i)

Noun 2

ì¹˜ â€¢ (chi) (hanja å¯¸)

  1. (unit of measure) A chi or Korean inch, a unit of length equivalent to about 3.03Â cm.
Synonyms
  • ì´Œ (chon)

Etymology 3

Suffix

â€”ì¹˜ â€¢ (-chi) (hanja å€¤)

  1. value.
    ê³„ì‚°ì¹˜. ì¸¡ì •ì¹˜.
Synonyms
  • ê°’ (gap)

Etymology 4

Contraction.

Suffix

â€”ì¹˜ â€¢ (-chi)

  1. contraction of í•˜ì§€.
    ì¤‘ìš”ì¹˜ ì•Šë‹¤.

í•´ - Wiktionary

Korean

Etymology 1

í•´í•µí•¶í•·í•¸í•¹í•º
í•»í•¼í•½í•¾í•¿í–€í–
í–‚í–ƒí–„í–…í–†í–‡í–ˆ
í–‰í–Ší–‹í–Œí–í–í–
í•˜ â†â†’ í–

Syllable

í•´ â€¢ (hae)

  1. A Hangul syllabic block made up of ã… and ã….

Etymology 2

First attested in the Yongbi eocheonga (é¾é£›å¾¡å¤©æ­Œ / ìš©ë¹„ì–´ì²œê°€), 1447, as Middle Korean á„’á†¡ (hoy).

Pronunciation

  • IPA(key)[heÌ]
  • Phonetic Hangul[í•´]
Revised Romanization? hae
Revised Romanization (translit.)? hae
McCuneâ€“Reischauer? hae
Yale Romanization? hay

Noun

í•´ â€¢ (hae)

  1. the Sun
    Synonym: íƒœì–‘ (taeyang)
    Antonym: ë‹¬ (dal)
    • í•´ê°€ ì„œìª½ì—ì„œ ëœ¨ë‹¤.
      Haega seojjogeseo tteuda.
      (saying) The Sun rises from the west; i.e. something impossible.
  2. sunlight, sunbeam
    • ì´ ë°©ì€ í•´ê°€ ì˜ ë“ ë‹¤.
      I bang-eun haega jal deunda.
      This room is well-illuminated by sunlight.
  3. daytime
    Synonyms: ë‚  (nal), ë‚® (nat)
  4. year
    Synonym: ë…„ (nyeon)
Derived terms
Derived terms

  • í–…ìŒ€ (haepssal, â€œrice of the yearâ€)
  • í–‡ê²ƒ (haetgeot, â€œproduce of the yearâ€)
  • í–‡ê·€ (haetgwi, â€œsunbeam (literally, "sun's ear")â€)
  • í–‡ë¬´ë¦¬ (haenmuri, â€œsolar haloâ€)

  • í–‡ë¹› (haetbit, â€œsunlightâ€)
  • í–‡ì‚´ (haetsal, â€œsunbeamâ€)

Prefix

í•´â€” â€¢ (hae-)

  1. white
Derived terms

  • í•´ë§‘ë‹¤ (haemakda, â€œto be white and cleanâ€)

í™” - Wiktionary

Korean

Etymology 1

í™”í™•í™–í™—í™˜í™™í™š
í™›í™œí™í™í™Ÿí™ í™¡
í™¢í™£í™¤í™¥í™¦í™§í™¨
í™©í™ªí™«í™¬í™­í™®í™¯
í˜¸ â†â†’ í™°

Syllable

í™” â€¢ (hwa)

  1. A Hangul syllabic block made up of ã… and ã…˜.

Etymology 2

Reading of various Chinese characters.

Pronunciation

  • IPA(key)[É¸waÌ Ë]
  • Phonetic Hangul[í™”]
Revised Romanization? hwa
Revised Romanization (translit.)? hwa
McCuneâ€“Reischauer? hwa
Yale Romanization? hwÄ

Noun

í™” â€¢ (hwa)

  1. (ç«) fire (usually used in compounds)
    Synonym: ë¶ˆ (bul)
  2. (ç«) anger
    í™”ê°€ ë‚˜ë‹¤ (hwaga nada) â€” one becomes angry
    ê·¸ ì—¬ìëŠ” ì™œ í™”ê°€ ë‚¬ìŠµë‹ˆê¹Œ?
    Geu yeojaneun wae hwaga natseumnikka?
    Why was she angry?

Abbreviation

í™” â€¢ (hwa)

  1. Abbreviation of í™”ìš”ì¼ (hwayoil): Tuesday

Syllable

í™” (hwa)

  1. ç« - fire, Tuesday
  2. èŠ± - flower
  3. è¯ - China
  4. è©± - talk; episode (in a book, series, etc.)
  5. ç•µ - picture
  6. åŒ– - transformation
  7. å’Œ - harmony
  8. é´ - shoe
